(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1982 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now
convened."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–1282. National Organization for Women, Inc., et al., Appel-
lants v. Idaho, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Idaho;
No. 81-1283. National Organization for Women, Inc., et al., Petition-
ers v. Idaho, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit before judgment;
No. 81–1312. Gerald P. Carmen, Administrator, General Services,
Appellant v. Idaho, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Idaho; and
No. 81-1313. Gerald P. Carmen, Administrator, General Services,
Petitioner v. Idaho, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit before judgment. Upon consid-
eration of the memorandum for the Administrator of General Services
suggesting mootness, filed July 9, 1982, and the responses thereto, the
judgment of the United States District Court for the District of Idaho is
vacated and the cases remanded to that Court with instructions to dis-
miss the complaints as moot. United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340
U.S. 36 (1950).
No. 81-2019. County of Arlington, Virginia, Appellant v. United
States, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and
Justice Stevens would affirm the judgment.

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1982
No. 81–2077. Gary D. Thompson, Appellant v. Indiana. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 81–2176. William L. Fisher, Appellant v. Robert C. Anderson.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-2197. Mary C. Kranda, Appellant v. Houser-Norborg Medical
Corporation and Keim T. Houser. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81-2310. Thophaus Ellerbe, Appellant v. Otis Elevator Com-
pany. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, First Supreme Judi-
cial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81–2377. Vera Gianechini, Individually and as Tutrix of the Es-
tate of David Gianechini, etc., Appellant v. City of New Orleans, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-2383. Boswell, Inc., dba Broadacres, Appellant v. Joseph F.
Harkins, Secretary, Kansas Department of Health and Environment;
and Boswell, Inc., dba Reno County Adult Care Home, Appellant v. Jo-
seph F. Harkins, Secretary, Kansas Department of Health and Envi-
ronment. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-2403. Marilyn Threlkeld and Daniel Hanka, Appellants v.
Robbinsdale Federation of Teachers, Local 872, AFL-CIO, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 81-6818. Edward D. Christensen, Appellant v. Utah. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Utah. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 82-5. Superior Oil Company, Appellant v. City of Port Arthur,
Texas, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, Ninth Su-
preme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
No. 82-77. William N. Griffin, et al., Appellants v. Burnes E. Sims,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
3
No. 82–135. Sears, Roebuck and Company, Appellant v. Washington
Department of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Washing-
ton. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82–159. Syracuse Savings Bank, et al., Appellants v. Town of
Dewitt. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-5022. Dennis Flowers, Appellant v. Colorado. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 82-5046. Owen W. Crumpacker, Appellant v. Indiana Supreme
Court Disciplinary Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Court of In-
diana. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 81–2080. Russell Stover Candies, Inc., Appellant v. Department
of Revenue of the State of Montana. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Montana. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Montana for further consideration in light of F.W.
Woolworth Co. v. Taxation & Revenue Department of New Mexico, 458
U.S. - (1982); and ASARCO, Inc. v. Idaho State Tax Commission,
_
458 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-2084. Mark Izzard, et al., Appellants v. Florida. Appeal from
the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 81-2113. Paul Allen Cooper, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 81-2213. Wake County Hospital System, Inc., et al., Appellants
v. News & Observer Publishing Company, et al. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of North Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.

son. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Eastern District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1653. University of Houston, et al., Petitioners v. Jeannine
W. Wilkins and Sharon D. Hill. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Pullman-Standard v. Swint, 456
U.S. (1982) and General Telephone Co. of Southwest v. Falcon,
457 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-1778. California, Petitioner v. David Wendell Ruggles. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second
Appellate District. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District, for further
consideration in light of United States v. Ross, 456 U.S. -
-
(1982).
No. 81-2049. United States, Petitioner v. Carlos Armijo-Martinez
and Carlos Armijo-DeLeon. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of re-
spondent Carlos Armijo-DeLeon for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. The motion of respondent Carlos Armijo-Martinez for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further
consideration in light of United States v. Valenzuela-Bernal, 458 U.S.
(1982).
No. 81-2189. County of Los Angeles, Petitioner v. Charles L. Jor-
dan. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of General Telephone Co. of Southwest v. Falcon, 457
U.S. (1982). Justice White dissents.
-
No. 81-2283. Western Conference of Teamsters Pension Trust Fund,
Petitioner v. Frank Music. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of United Mine Workers of America
Health and Retirement Funds v. Robinson, 455 U.S. (1982). Jus-
tice White and Justice Blackmun dissent and would deny certiorari.
-

MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
9
No. 81-6713. Bryant R. Britt, Petitioner v. Simi Valley Unified
School District, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of cer-
tiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Patsy v. Bd. of Regents of Florida, 457 U.S.
(1982).

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES

Allan B. Sumner, et al., Petitioners v. United States;
Ernest R. Zerman, Petitioner v. Harry A. Jacobs, et al.;
Frank J. Souza, et al., Petitioners v. Trustees of the West-
ern Conference of Teamsters Pension Trust. The motions to direct the

rections, Applicant v. Charles William Bass. The application to vacate
the stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Rehn-
quist and by him referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-279. Henry E. Williams, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Powell and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-274. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard G. Kleindienst.
Disbarment entered. Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this order.
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California et al.
The motion of Pyramid Lake Indian Tribe for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The Exceptions to the Report of the Special
Master are set for oral argument in due course. The motion of Arizona,
et al. for leave to file a brief in response to the reply briefs of the United
States, et al. is granted. Justice Marshall took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of these motions and this order.
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor;
David H. Leroy, Attorney General; Joseph C. Greenley, Director, De-
partment of Fish and Game, Plaintiffs v. States of Oregon and Wash-
ington. The Final Report of the Special Master is received and ordered
filed. Exceptions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be filed by
the parties within 45 days. Replies to such Exceptions, with supporting
briefs, may be filed within 30 days.

No. 73, Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Nevada. It
is ordered that the Honorable Robert Van Pelt is discharged as Special
Master in this case.

et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 80-1074. Richard W. Velde, et al., Petitioners v. National Black
Police Association, Inc., et al. The motion of respondents to defer tax-
ation of costs is denied. Justice Powell and Justice Stevens took no part
in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 80-1735. Federal Bureau of Investigation, et al., Petitioners v.
Howard S. Abramson. The motion of respondent for reconsideration of
taxation of costs is denied.
No. 80–1991. Oregon, Petitioner v. Bruce Alan Kennedy. The motion
of respondent to retax costs is denied.
No. 81-1. Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States; and
No. 81-3. Bob Jones University, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of National Association of Independent Schools for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Lawrence E. Lewy for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Inde-
pendent Sector for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of International Human Rights Law Group for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Anti-Defamation
League of B'nai B'rith for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motions for divided argument and for additional time for
oral argument are granted and a total of one hour and fifteen minutes is
allotted for oral argument to be divided as follows: 15 minutes for
Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc.; 15 minutes for Bob Jones University;
15 minutes for the United States; and 30 minutes for William T. Cole-
man, Jr., Esquire, as amicus curiae.
No. 81–185. Chris Simopoulos, Appellant v. Virginia. The motion of
American Public Health Association for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted. The motion of Women Lawyers of Sacramento, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of The
Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 81-523. Container Corporation of America, Appellant v. Fran-
chise Tax Board. The motion of International Bankers Association in
California, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Jus-
tice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

No. 81-2125. Terrel H. Bell, Secretary of Education, Petitioner v.
New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 81-2337. John R. Block, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. North Dakota, ex rel. Board of University and School Lands.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit granted.

pital. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of
Massachusetts granted.

Allen, Jr., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted.
No. 81-1889. Public Service Commission of the State of New York,
Petitioner v. Mid-Louisiana Gas Company, et al.;
No. 81-1958. Arizona Electric Power Cooperative, Inc., Petitioner v.
Mid-Louisiana Gas Company, et al.;
No. 81-2042. Michigan, Petitioner v. Mid-Louisiana Gas Company, et
al.; and
No. 82–19. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Petitioner v.
Mid-Louisiana Gas Company, et al. The motion of Public Utilities Com-
mission of the State of California, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae in Nos. 81-1889, 81-1958 and 81-2042 is granted. The motion of
Associated Gas Distributors for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae in
No. 81-1889 is granted. The motion of National Rural Electric Coopera-
tive Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of Edmund G. Brown, Jr., Governor of California, for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The petitions for writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted
for oral argument.
No. 81–1891. Morrison-Knudsen Construction Company, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation, United States
Department of Labor, et al. The motion of American Insurance Associ-
ation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of
Alliance of American Insurers, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted. The motion of National Association of Stevedores for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum-
bia Circuit granted.

16
MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
No. 81-1893. California, Petitioner v. Marcelino Ramos. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California granted.
No. 81-2147. Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. San Carlos Apache Tribe
of Arizona, et al.; and Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. Navajo Tribe of
Indians, et al.; and
No. 81-2188. Montana, et al., Petitioners v. Northern Cheyenne
Tribe of the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation, et al. The peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one
and one-half hours are allotted for oral argument.
No. 81-2318. Florida, Petitioner v. Constantino Casal and Omar Gar-
cia. The motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Flor-
ida granted.
No. 82–131. Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, etc., Petitioner v.
Howard E. Pfeifer. The motion of Keystone Shipping Company, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit granted limited to Questions I and II presented by the petition.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 80, Original. State of Colorado, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico
and Robert K. Corbin, Attorney General of New Mexico. Argued by
Mr. Richard A. Simms for the defendants and by Mr. Robert F.
Welborn for the plaintiff.
No. 81-776. Ted W. Brown, et al., Appellants v. Socialist Workers
'74 Campaign Committee (Ohio), et al. Argued by Mr. Gary Elson
Brown for the appellants and by Mr. Thomas D. Buckley, Jr. for the
appellees.
No. 81–897. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, Petitioner v. Perini North River
Associates, et al. Argued by Mr. Richard G. Wilkins for the petitioner,
pro hac vice, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Martin Krutzel for
the respondents.
No. 81-878. John P. Larkin, et al., Appellants v. Grendel's Den, Inc.
Argued by Mr. Gerald J. Caruso for the appellants, pro hac vice, by
special leave of Court, and by Mr. Laurence H. Tribe for the appellee.
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. 81–150. Northern Pipeline Construction Co., Appellant v. Mara-
thon Pipe Line Company and United States; and
No. 81-546. United States, Appellant v. Marathon Pipe Line Co., et
al. Upon consideration of the motion of the Solicitor General to extend

MONDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1982
91
stay of judgment, and the responses thereto, it is ordered that the
Clerk shall further stay the sending of the certified copy of the judg-
ment to the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota
to and including December 24, 1982.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v. Maria Antonieta Plasencia.

Manulkin for the respondent.

tioner v. California State Council of Carpenters and Carpenters 46
Northern Counties Conference Board, et al. Argued by Mr. James P.
Watson for the petitioner and by Mr. Victor J. Van Bourg for the
respondents.

tional Facility, Petitioner v. Robert Lonberger. Argued by Mr. Richard

respondent.

v. Wyoming, et al. Argued by Mr. Solicitor General Rex E. Lee for the
appellant and by Mr. Bruce A. Salzburg for the appellees.

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 81-708. City of Port Arthur, Texas, Appellant v. United States,
et al. Argued by Mr. Robert Q. Keith for the appellant and by Mr. Car-
ter G. Phillips for the appellees.
No. 81-525. Charles V. Bowen, Petitioner v. United States Postal
Service, et al. Argued by Mr. William B. Poff for the petitioner, by Ms.
Barbara E. Etkind for the federal respondent in support of the peti-
tioner, and by Mr. Asher W. Schwartz for the respondent Union.
No. 81–184. United States, Appellant v. Security Industrial Bank, et
al. Argued by Mr. Alan I. Horowitz for the appellant and by Mr. Henry
F. Field for the appellees.
No. 81-825. The Pillsbury Company, et al., Petitioners v. John
Conboy. Argued by Mr. Francis J. McConnell for the petitioners and by
Mr. Michael W. Coffield for the respondent.
Adjourned until Tuesday, October 12, 1982 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1982
97
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–240. Alexander Theoharous, Appellant v. Deer Run Shores
Property Owners Association, Inc. Appeal from the Small Claims Ses-
sion, Superior Court of Connecticut. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82-5204. Edward Wayland, Appellant v. Registry of Deeds, Sa-
lem, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 82-245. Andrea Cisneros Jalifi, Appellant v. Industrial Commis-
sion of Arizona, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Di-
vision One. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Justice White would note probable jurisdiction and set the
case for oral argument.
No. 82-288. A. Robert Kleiner, et al., Appellants v. Richard
Sanderson, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Michigan. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set
the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-6782. Michael Mack, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the pe-
tition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for
further consideration in light of United States v. Johnson, 457 U.S.
(1982). Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice
Rehnquist joins.

98
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1982
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Archie L. Hull, etc., Petitioner v. City of Duncanville. The
motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition for writ of certiorari is
denied.
No. . Oklahoma, Petitioner v. Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific
Railroad Company. The motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition
for writ of certiorari is denied.
No. A-281. Peter Filipas and Emma Filipas, Applicants v. Addie Lee
Lemons. The application for a further extension of time within which to
file a petition for a writ of certiorari presented to Justice O'Connor and
by her referred to the Court is granted and the time for filing a petition
for writ of certiorari is extended to and including November 26, 1982.
No. A-283. Mashapee Tribe, et al., Applicants v. James G. Watt, et
al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred
to the Court is denied.
No. A-294. W. P. McDonald, etc., Applicant v. Braniff Airways,
Inc., et al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and
referred to the Court is denied.
No. 81–802. City of Lockhart, Appellant v. United States and Alfred
Cano. The motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument is
denied.
No. 81-1314. W. R. Grace and Company, Petitioner v. Local Union
No. 759, International Union of the United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum
and Plastic Workers of America. The motion of the Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.
No. 81-1636. Florida, Petitioner v. Frank J. Brady, et al. The motion
of Western Growers Association for leave to file a brief as amicus cu-
riae is granted.
No. 81-2101. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al., Petitioners
v. Terri Lee Halderman, et al. The motion of respondents Halderman,
et al. to dismiss the writ of certiorari as improvidently granted is
denied.
No. 82–227. Providence Journal Company, Petitioner v. Home Place-
ment Service, Inc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 82–282. Thomas C. McCain and William Spencer, etc., Appel-
lants v. Charles E. Lybrand, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1982
99
No. 82-287. Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. Ash Grove Cement Com-
pany, et al. The motion of petitioners to defer consideration of the peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is granted. The motion of respondents for
leave to file typewritten supplemental brief in opposition to petition for
a writ of certiorari is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of these motions.
No. 82–392. Monex International, Ltd., et al., Petitioners v. Com-
modity Futures Trading Commission, et al. The motion of petitioners
for simultaneous consideration of this case with No. 82-24, Federal
Trade Commission v. Francis Ford, Inc., is denied.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 82-11. Mennonite Board of Missions, Appellant v. Richard C.
Adams. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Indiana. In this case prob-
able jurisdiction is noted.

States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.

ment Opportunity Commission. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

Company. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Oklahoma denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom
Justice White joins.

for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White.

Texas, Ninth Supreme Judicial District, denied. Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice White and Justice O'Connor would grant certiorari.

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the

certiorari.

petition for writ of certiorari.

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina denied.

tice Marshall.

the Ninth Circuit denied. The Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

for writs of habeas corpus are denied.

ORDER
Pursuant to the provisions of Title 28, U.S.C., Section 42, it is or-
dered that the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, assigned to the Fed-
eral Circuit as Circuit Justice, effective October 1, 1982.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 18, 1982, until
Monday, November 1, 1982.

States; and

hour and fifteen minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr.
William B. Ball for the petitioner Bob Jones University, by Mr. William
G. McNairy for the petitioner Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc., by Mr.
William Bradford Reynolds for the United States, and by Mr. William
T. Coleman, Jr. as amicus curiae in support of the judgment below.
No. 81–298. Community Television of Southern California, Petitioner
v. Sue Gottfried, et al.; and
No. 81-799. Federal Communications Commission, Petitioner v. Sue
Gottfried, et al. One hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argu-
ment. Argued by Mr. Edgar F. Czarra, Jr. for the petitioner in No.
81-298, by Mr. Samuel A. Alito, Jr. for the petitioner in No. 81-799,
and by Mr. Charles M. Firestone for the respondents in both cases.

minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Calvin L. Fox for
the petitioner, by Mr. Andrew L. Frey for the United States as amicus
curiae, and by Mr. Theodore Klein for the respondent.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1982
121
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–105. California, et al., Appellants v. Maurice John Keenan.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The motion of appellee
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82–381. Bethlehem Steel Corporation, et al., Appellants v.
Rhode Island Turnpike and Bridge Authority. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Rhode Island. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-299. Janice Hayes, Applicant v. Justices of the Supreme Court
of Nevada, et al. The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-260. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard M. Bussey. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-265. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur H. Grant. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-269. In the Matter of Disbarment of Callis N. Brown. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-273. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard P. Micun. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-276. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael W. Hubbard.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-282. In the Matter of Michael Levine. Due to mistaken iden-
tity, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial Department, having two attorneys on its roster with identical
names, the Rule to Show Cause is discharged and the order entered
September 9, 1982, is vacated.

122
MONDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1982
No. D-293. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene William Doyle. It
is ordered that Eugene William Doyle, of San Francisco, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-294. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter Wolff. It is ordered
that Peter Wolff, of Washington, District of Columbia, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-295. In the Matter of Disbarment of J. Hudson Moyer. It is
ordered that J. Hudson Moyer, of Amarillo, Texas, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-296. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick L. Coleman,
Jr. It is ordered that Frederick L. Coleman, Jr., of Big Spring, Texas,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-297. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lynn R. Jeffcoat. It is
ordered that Lynn R. Jeffcoat, of Richardson, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-298. In the Matter of Disbarment of George Ralph Burger. It
is ordered that George Ralph Burger, of Sandy Springs, Georgia, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California, et
al. The joint motion for additional time for oral argument and for di-
vided argument is granted and a total of one and one-half hours is allot-
ted for oral argument and no more than two counsel per side shall
present oral argument. Justice Marshall took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this motion.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed. Excep-
tions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be filed by the parties
within 45 days. Replies to such Exceptions, with supporting briefs, may
be filed within 30 days.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1982
123
No. 89, Original. State of California, ex rel. State Lands Commis-
sion, Plaintiff v. United States. Final decree entered.
No. 92, Original. State of Arkansas, Plaintiff v. State of Mississippi.
The Answer to the Counterclaim is referred to the Special Master.
No. 81-395. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC, Peti-
tioner v. Edward Sadlowski, Jr., et al. The motion of respondents to
dispense with taxation of costs is denied.
No. 81–460. Middlesex County Ethics Committee, etc., Petitioner v.
Garden State Bar Association, et al. The motion of respondents to retax
costs is denied.
No. 81-746. City of Akron, Petitioner v. Akron Center for Reproduc-
tive Health, Inc., et al.; and
No. 81–1172. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, Inc., et al., Pe-
titioners v. City of Akron, et al. The motion of The Board of Church and
Society of the United Methodist Church, et al. for leave to join the
brief, amicus curiae, of Certain Religious Organizations is denied.
No. 81-878. John P. Larkin, et al., Appellants v. Grendel's Den, Inc.
The motion of appellee for leave to file supplemental statement after
argument is granted.
No. 81-1055. David B. Poythress, et al., Petitioners v. Elizabeth B.
Duncan, et al. Oral argument in this case, presently scheduled for No-
vember 1, 1982, is hereby postponed and the case of Federal Election
Commission, et al. v. National Right to Work Committee, et al., No.
81-1506, is set for oral argument in its stead.
No. 81-1120. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Richard W.
Rylander, Sr., as President of Rylander & Co. Realtors, Inc., et al. The
motion of respondents for leave to argue points not raised by petition-
ers is denied.
No. 81-1536. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. John
F. Tufts, et al. The motion of Wayne G. Barnett for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-1717. American Bank and Trust Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Dallas County, et al. The motion of Texas Association of Appraisal
Districts, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is denied. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 82–55. City of West Helena, Arkansas, et al., Appellants v. P. L.
Perkins, et al. The application for the issuance of the judgment forth-
with presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the Court is
granted and the judgment is to issue forthwith.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1982
141
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-396. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of Cor-
rections, Applicant v. Ronald Clark O'Bryan. The application to vacate
the stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Rehnquist would
grant the application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982
143
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 81-2066. Charles E. Anderson, Warden, Petitioner v. Jack E.
Harless. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–139. Jacoby & Meyers, Appellant v. Supreme Court of New
Jersey, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
White and Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set
the case for oral argument. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this appeal.
No. 82-309. Mary K. Smith, et al., Appellants v. S. David Brandt,
President, State Board of Education, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 82–347. C. Lawrence Wiser, Appellant v. Harry R. Hughes,
Governor of Maryland; and
No. 82-5360. Richard L. Andrews, Appellant v. Harry R. Hughes,
Governor of Maryland. Appeals from the Court of Appeals of Maryland.
The appeals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-402. Robert L. Durning, Jr., Trustee of the Estate of R. L.
Durning, Appellant v. City of Louisville, et al. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.

144
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982
No. 82-360. William L. Burton, et al., Appellants v. Walker Hobbie,
Jr., etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Alabama. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 82-5372. Jack Ma, Appellant v. The Community Bank. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82-5376. Orville J. Latendresse and Ruth Latendresse, Appel-
lants v. Albert Latendresse. Appeal from the Supreme Court of North
Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-325. David Grant Gifford, Applicant v. United States. The
application for bail addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-390. Richard Cepulonis, etc., et al., Applicants v. James Mi-
chael Connolly, et al. The application for an injunction addressed to Jus-
tice Stevens and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-285. In the Matter of Disbarment of George N. Gloeckner.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-297. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lynn R. Jeffcoat. Lynn
R. Jeffcoat, of Richardson, Texas, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September 9,
1982, is hereby discharged.
No. 9, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of Loui-
siana, et al. The petition of the Special Master, Walter P. Armstrong,
Jr., for allowance of interim compensation and expenses, as set forth in
the petition filed October 18, 1982, is granted, and it is ordered that the
United States bear one half of the costs and the States of Mississippi
and Alabama each bear one quarter of the costs. Justice Marshall took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 88, Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Texas, et al.
It is ordered that the Honorable Wade H. McCree, Jr. of Ann Arbor,

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982
145
Michigan, is appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix
the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to di-
rect subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses,
issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such
as he may deem necessary to call for. The Special Master is directed to
submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him, the
compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, clerical and legal as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion
as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this case
becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall
have authority to make a new designation which shall have the same
effect as if originally made by the Court herein.
The notice of dismissal of certain defendants is referred to the Special
Master.
No. 81-3. Bob Jones University, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to file a supplemental brief after argu-
ment is granted.
No. 81-920. Verlinden B. V., Petitioner v. Central Bank of Nigeria.
Stephen N. Shulman, Esquire, of Washington, D.C., a member of the
Bar of this Court, is invited to argue this case, as amicus curiae, in sup-
port of the judgment below.
No. 81-1320. William Kolender, et al., Appellants v. Edward
Lawson. Treating appellee's letter of October 19, 1982, as a motion for
leave to present oral argument pro se, the motion is denied. Mark D.
Rosenbaum, Esquire, of Los Angeles, California, a member of the Bar
of this Court, is invited to argue this case, as amicus curiae, in support
of the judgment below.
No. 81–1493. The Gillette Company, Petitioner v. Steven Miner. The
motion of Consumer Coalition for leave to participate in oral argument
as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 81-1618. Weyerhaeuser Company and Willamette Industries,
Inc., Petitioners v. Lyman Lamb Company, et al.; and
No. 81-1619. Georgia-Pacific Corporation, Petitioner v. Lyman Lamb
Company, et al. The motion of Alaska, et al. for leave to participate in
oral argument as amici curiae and for additional time for oral argument
is denied. The motion of National Lumber and Building Material Deal-
ers Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Jus-
tice White took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.

146
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982
No. 81-1893. California, Petitioner v. Marcelino Ramos. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Ezra Hen-
don, Esquire, of San Francisco, California, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 82–233. Owen H. Brooks, et al., Appellants v. William F. Win-
ter, Governor of Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 82-413. William F. Winter, Governor of Mississippi, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Owen H. Brooks, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file
a brief in these case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 82–610. In Re Alwin E. Hopfmann, et al., Petitioners. The mo-
tion of petitioner to expedite consideration of the petition for a writ of
prohibition and/or mandamus and/or injunction is denied. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Powell and referred to the Court is
denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 82-25. Albert A. Jones, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Richard S.
Schweiker, Secretary, Department of Health and Human Services. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted.
No. 82-91. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Padungsri Phinpathya. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 82–401. Baxter Rice, Individually and as Director of the Depart-
ment of Alcoholic Beverage Control of California, Petitioner v. Eva
Rehner. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 81–1717. American Bank and Trust Company, et al., Petitioners
v. Dallas County, et al. The motion of American Bankers Association
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Dale
National Bank for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fifth
Supreme Judicial District, granted limited to Question 1 presented by
the petition. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions and this petition.
No. 81–1857. Oregon, Petitioner v. James Edward Bradshaw. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Oregon
granted.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982
147
No. 81-2399. Metropolitan Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
People Against Nuclear Energy, et al.; and
No. 82-358. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. People Against Nuclear Energy, et al. The motion of
Atomic Industrial Forum for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of American Mining Congress for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of The Chamber of Com-
merce of the United States for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted. The cases are con-
solidated and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 82–23. Frank Marsh, State Treasurer, et al., Petitioners v. Er-
nest Chambers. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is granted limited to
Question 4 presented by the petition.
No. 82–167. George C. Chappell, et al., Petitioners v. Vernon Wal-
lace, et al. The motion of respondents Vernon Wallace, et al. for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
No. 82–185. Boston Firefighters Union, Local 718, Petitioner v. Bos-
ton Chapter, NAACP, et al.;
No. 82-246. Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, Inc., Petitioner
v. Pedro Castro, et al.; and
No. 82–259. Nancy B. Beecher, et al., Petitioners v. Boston Chapter,
NAACP, et al. The motion of International Association of Fire Fight-
ers, AFL-CIO for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae in No. 82-185 is
granted. The petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and
a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
CERTIORARI DENIED

R. Williams. The motion of respondent Williams for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.
No. 82–393. Western Electric Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Ollie T.
Hill, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Powell would grant the
petition for certiorari, vacate the judgment, and remand the case to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of General Telephone Co. of the Southwest v. Falcon,
457 U.S. - (1982).
No. 82–399. Span-Deck, Inc., Petitioner v. Fabcon, Incorporated and
Rauenhorst Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Justice Black-
mun took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1982
171
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 82–29. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Horacio Ramos Miranda. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–284. International Association of Machinists and Aerospace
Workers, et al., Appellants v. Federal Election Commission, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Colum-
bia Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 82-290. The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United
States, Appellant v. The Finance Administration of the City of New
York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 82–293. North Shore University Hospital, et al., Appellants v.
State Human Rights Appeal Board, et al. Appeal from the Appellate
Division, Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial Department.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Blackmun
would dismiss the appeal for want of a substantial federal question. Jus-
tice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 82-5488. Edward Wayland, Appellant v. Internal Revenue Serv-
ice, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.

No. -
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1982
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Daniel Ross, Petitioner v. James C. Woodard, Chairman,
North Carolina Parole Commission. The motion to direct the Clerk to
file the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. D-262. In the Matter of Disbarment of John F. Auwaerter. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-267. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles DeFazio, III.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-286. In the Matter of Disbarment of Floyd Norman Nadler.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-290. In the Matter of Disbarment of Demetri M. Spiro.
Demetri M. Spiro, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September 9,
1982, is hereby discharged.
No. D-299. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ellis Olkon. It is ordered
that Ellis Olkon, of St. Louis Park, Minnesota, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-300. In the Matter of Disbarment of John M. Grubor. It is or-
dered that John M. Grubor, of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-301. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robbin James Bonnin. It
is ordered that Robbin James Bonnin, of Amherst, Michigan, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–302. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Vernon Johnson.
It is ordered that Richard Vernon Johnson, of Baltimore, Maryland, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81-1618. Weyerhaeuser Company and Willamette Industries,
Inc., Petitioners v. Lyman Lamb Company, et al.; and
No. 81-1619. Georgia-Pacific Corporation, Petitioner v. Lyman Lamb

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1982
173
Company, et al. The motion of respondents for relief from compliance
with Rule 28.1 is granted. Justice White, Justice Powell and Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 81-1636. Florida, Petitioner v. Frank J. Brady, et al. The parties
are directed to file supplemental memoranda addressing the present
posture of the cases in the state courts, the status of the charges
against each respondent and how any change, if there be any change,
affects the case pending in this Court. Oral argument in this case, pres-
ently scheduled for December 8, 1982, is postponed and the case of Dis-
trict of Columbia Court of Appeals v. Feldman and Hickey, No.
81-1335, is set for oral argument in its stead.
No. 82–171. Marine Terminals Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. John
F. Kelly. The motion of John F. Kelly for reimbursement of costs is
denied.
No. 82-446. Dallas County Hospital District, Petitioner v. Dallas As-
sociation of Community Organizations for Reform Now, et al. The mo-
tion of respondent Leon Gowans for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is denied.
No. 82-667. Florida, Petitioner v. Silvio P. Zafra. The motion of peti-
tioner to expedite consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari is
denied.

ture Technology, Inc. v. National Fuel Gas Distribution Corp., et al.,
post.
No. 82–280. Charles H. Sylvain, Petitioner v. Priscilla S. Henderson,
Executrix, Estate of Eudore J. Sylvain. The motion of petitioner for
leave to add party as respondent is denied. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of New Hampshire denied.
-
No. 82–362. Venture Technology, Inc., Petitioner v. National Fuel
Gas Distribution Corporation, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice White in this case and in No. 82-277,
Schwimmer, Mendel, etc. v. Sony Corp., ante.
No. 82-365. Aileen Love, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. William Earl
Stacy. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied.
No. 82-396. Twin City Sportservice, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Charles O. Finley & Company, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied. Jus-
tice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 82-444. Greitzer & Locks, et al., Petitioners v. Johns-Manville
Corporation, et al. The motion of respondents to defer consideration of
the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit de-
nied. Justice Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion and this petition.
No. 82-453. Francis Oil & Gas, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Exxon Cor-
poration, et al. The motion of Independent Petroleum Association of
America, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The
motion of Texas Independent Producers Legal Action Association, et
al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Temporary Emergency Court of Ap-
peals denied.

182
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1982
No. 82-5053. Kenneth Lewis McCallum, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice Powell took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this petition.
No. 82-5315. John BB and Stephen CC, Petitioners v. New York. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied.
Justice White would grant certiorari.
REHEARINGS DENIED

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1982
193
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–149. Black Construction Corporation, Appellant v. Joshua C.
Agsalud, Director of the Department of Labor and Industrial Rela-
tions, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-482. William L. Hamilton and Juanita S. Mead, Appellants v.
Virginia. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-5433. Yvonne Cavanaugh, etc., Appellant v. Colorado De-
partment of Social Services. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Colo-
rado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-519. Joseph P. Counihan, Jr., as Temporary Administrator of
the Estate of Anne Fahey Counihan, et al., Appellants v. Department
of Transportation of Georgia, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Justice Black-
mun and Justice O'Connor would dismiss the appeal for want of a prop-
erly presented federal question.
No. 82-592. Henry Timothy Foulds, Appellant v. Pennsylvania.
Appeal from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Office.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1055. David B. Poythress, et al., Petitioners v. Elizabeth
B. Duncan, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as
improvidently granted.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-392. Joseph Albano, Jr., et al., Applicants v. United States.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Brennan and referred to
the Court is denied.

194
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1982
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California, et
al. The motion of Quechan Tribe for modification of the order granting
divided argument is denied. Justice Marshall took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this motion.

Stephens. The parties are invited to file within thirty days supplemen-
tal memoranda addressing the opinion of the Supreme Court of Geor-
gia, Case No. 38763, decided October 27, 1982, and its effect on the case
pending before this Court.

The motion of respondents for divided argument is denied.

Eicke. The motion of Martin S. Sanders, Jr., Esquire, to permit Martin

ers, et al.; and United States, Petitioner v. Joerene Ingram, et al. The
motion of respondents for divided argument is granted.

The motion of New York for leave to file an out-of-time motion for di-
vided argument is denied.

trial Organizations, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is

et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

granted.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1982
211
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 82–158. Donald W. Wyrick, Warden, Petitioner v. Edward
Fields. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Disssenting opin-
ion by Justice Marshall.
No. 82-5082. Robert C. Griggs and Jacqueline M. Griggs, Petitioners
v. Provident Consumer Discount Company. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari and motion of petitioners for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-567. Howard A. Williams, et ux., Appellants v. Cheetwood &
Davies. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Wood County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-573. South Carolina State Conference of Branches of the
NAACP, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Richard W. Riley, Governor of the
State of South Carolina, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of South Carolina. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 82-574. Nancy L. Stevenson and L. Marion Gressette, Appel-
lants v. South Carolina State Conference of Branches of the National
Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Inc., et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of South Caro-
lina. The judgment is affirmed.

212
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1982
No. 82-576. Robert F. Pierce, et ux., Appellants v. Donald W.
Bierer, Jr., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Delaware. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
White, dissenting: I would note probable jurisdiction. The reasons for
doing so which I stated in dissent from dismissal at 434 U.S. 989 are
more telling now than they were then.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1998. Price Waterhouse, Petitioner v. Zelda L. Panzirer, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. In light of the respondent's suggestion of mootness and
the petitioner's response, the judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
with directions that it instruct the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York to dismiss the complaint with prejudice.
No. 82–327. Chicago Board Options Exchange, Incorporated, Peti-
tioner v. Board of Trade of the City of Chicago; and The Options Clear-
ing Corporation, Petitioner v. Board of Trade of the City of Chicago;
and
No. 82-526. Securities and Exchange Commission, Petitioner v.
Board of Trade of the City of Chicago, et al.; and Securities and Ex-·
change Commission, Petitioner v. Board of Trade of the City of Chi-
cago, et al. The motion of Securities Industry Association for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae in No. 82-327 is granted. Upon consider-
ation of the suggestions of mootness filed by the petitioners, the peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit are granted and the judgments are vacated and
these cases are remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to dis-
miss the petitions for review as moot. United States v. Munsingwear,
Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950). Justice White took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion and these cases.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Wampanoag Indian Nation, et al., Plaintiffs v. Massachu-
setts. The motion of plaintiffs for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied.
No. D-292. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Harold Fendler.
Robert Harold Fendler, of Phoenix, Arizona, having requested to re-
sign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on September
9, 1982, is hereby discharged.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1982
213
No. 80–1832. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Appellant v.
Jagdish Rai Chadha, et al.;
No. 80-2170. United States House of Representatives, Petitioner v.
Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al.; and
No. 80–2171. United States Senate, Petitioner v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service, et al. The motion of petitioner in No. 80-2170
for leave to file a supplemental brief on reargument is granted. The mo-
tion of petitioner in No. 80-2171 for leave to file a supplemental brief on
reargument is granted.
No. 81-430. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lance Gates, et ux. This case is re-
stored to the calendar for reargument. In addition to the question pre-
sented in the petition for certiorari and previously argued here, the
parties are requested to address the question whether the rule requir-
ing the exclusion at a criminal trial of evidence obtained in violation of
the Fourth Amendment, Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643 (1961); Weeks v.
United States, 232 U.S. 383 (1914), should to any extent be modified, so
as, for example, not to require the exclusion of evidence obtained in the
reasonable belief that the search and seizure at issue was consistent
with the Fourth Amendment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens
with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join.
No. 81–1114. Illinois, Petitioner v. Abbott & Associates, Inc., et al.
The motion of the Solicitor General to permit Richard G. Wilkins, Es-
quire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 81-1476. United States, Petitioner v. Lucille Mitzi Bosco Rodg-
ers, et al.; and United States, Petitioner v. Joerene Ingram, et al. The
motion of the Solicitor General to permit George W. Jones, Jr., Es-
quire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.
No. 81–1282. National Organization for Women, Inc., et al., Appel-
lants v. Idaho, et al.; and
No. 81-1312. Gerald P. Carmen, Administrator, General Services,
Appellant v. Idaho, et al. The motion of appellees to retax costs is
denied.
No. 81-1284. Johonnas Justus Eicke, Petitioner v. Elizabeth Larue
Eicke. The parties are directed to file within thirty days supplemental
memoranda addressing the Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act, 28
U.S.C. 1738A, and its effect on the case pending before this Court. Oral
argument in this case, presently scheduled for December 6, 1982, is
postponed and the case of United States v. Knotts, No. 81–1802, is set
for oral argument in its stead.

No. 81-6665. Raymond Edward James, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Opinion by Justice Brennan respecting the
denial of the petition for writ of certiorari with whom Justice Blackmun
joins.
No. 82-235. G. Patrick Morris, et al., Petitioners v. United States, et
al. The motion of petitioners to defer consideration of the petition for a
writ of certiorari is denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 82–267. D. J. McCarthy, Superintendent, California Men's Col-
ony, Petitioner v. Russell Lee Hinman. The motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
denied.

respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied.
No. 82-480. Joseph P. McCombs, Chairman, Illinois Prisoner Review
Board, Petitioner v. William Scott. The motion of respondent for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied.
No. 82-521. Everett Jones, Superintendent, Great Meadow Correc-
tional Facility, et al., Petitioners v. Pedro Arroyo. The motion of re-
spondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied.

Bloomsburg State College, et al. The motion of petitioner to amend pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 82–386. Kerr-McGee Chemical Corporation, Petitioner v. Illi-
nois. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Opinion by Justice Blackmun re-
specting the denial of the petition for writ of certiorari. Dissenting
opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 82–446. Dallas County Hospital District, Petitioner v. Dallas As-
sociation of Community Organizations for Reform Now, et al. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari and give this
case plenary consideration. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1982
241
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-638. Louisiana, Appellant v. Roy Hryhorchuk, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82-5678. Edward Wayland, Appellant v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.

OPINION
No. 81-1493. The Gillette Company, Petitioner v. Steven Miner. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. There being no final
judgment, the writ of certiorari is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1982

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 81-1635. John B. Anderson, et al., Petitioners v. Anthony J. Cel-
ebrezze, Jr., Secretary of State of Ohio. Argued by Mr. George T.
Frampton, Jr. for the petitioners and by Mr. Joel S. Taylor for the
respondent.
No. 81-1476. United States, Petitioner v. Lucille Mitzi Bosco Rodg-
ers, et al.; and United States, Petitioner v. Joerene Ingram, et al. Ar-
gued by Mr. George W. Jones for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special
leave of Court, by Mr. William D. Elliott for the respondents Rodgers,
et al. and by Mr. L. Lynn Elliott for the respondents Ingram and
Bates.
No. 81-1627. Larry Shepard, Petitioner v. National Labor Relations
Board, et al. Argued by Mr. Robert F. Gore for the petitioner and by
Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler for the respondents.
No. 81-1802. United States, Petitioner v. Leroy Carlton Knotts. Ar-
gued by Mr. Andrew L. Frey for the petitioner and by Mr. Mark W.
Peterson for the respondent.
The Chief Justice said:
"Last Wednesday, Marjorie Leonard Brennan, wife of Justice Bren-
nan, died, after a long and courageous struggle with illness. What
marked her in a very special way that all who knew her admired, was
her shining spirit and uncomplaining attitude. No one can really know
what that kind of courage, in the face of long illness, calls for, but
she inspired the love and admiration of all who knew her. Especially
those of us who saw her frequently, marvelled at her courage and
cheerfulness.
The light of her spirit will be sorely missed, not only by her family,
but all those who, over the years, witnessed her quiet strength, her
smile, her determination to carry on with life and live it to its fullest.
Marjorie Brennan truly lived her life to the fullest against great odds.
As a mark of our sorrow, and of our affection for her, and for our
Brother Justice Brennan and his family, and our deep and lasting affec-
tion for Marjorie Brennan, the Journal of the Court will record that ad-
journment of this Court today is in honor of her life, and her memory."
☑
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1982
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
253
No. 88, Original. State of California, Plaintiff v. State of Texas, et
al. The motion of plaintiff for issuance of a preliminary injunction is
granted. Comments by counsel for the defendants concerning the form
of the proposed order submitted by the plaintiff are to be filed with the
Court and served upon opposing counsel and the Special Master on or
before December 8, 1982.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-504. Charlie Brooks, Jr., Applicant v. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Di-
rector, Texas Department of Corrections. The application for a stay of
execution of the sentence of death presented to Justice White and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Treating the papers as a second
petition for rehearing of the order denying a petition for a writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas, rehearing is denied.
Treating the papers as a petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, or alternatively as a peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari before judgment to that Court, the petition
is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and
Justice Stevens.
