OPINIONS
No. 81-1453. South Dakota, Petitioner v. Mason Henry Neville. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Dakota. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of South Dakota for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens
with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 81–298. Community Television of Southern California, Petitioner
v. Sue Gottfried, et al.; and
No. 81-799. Federal Communications Commission, Petitioner v. Sue
Gottfried, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed insofar as
it vacated the order of the Federal Communications Commission and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 81-334. Associated General Contractors of California, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. California State Council of Carpenters and Carpenters 46
Northern Counties Conference Board, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.

414
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1983
No. 81-420. R.C. Marshall, Superintendent, Southern Ohio Correc-
tional Facility, Petitioner v. Robert Lonberger. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice
Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall, and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 81-638. Lowell D. Hewitt, et al., Petitioners v. Aaron Helms. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens
with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join, and with whom
Justice Blackmun joins as to Parts II and III.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 81-1020. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Ralph Eager-
ton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of Alabama, et al.; and
No. 81-1268. Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation, et al., Appellants v.
Ralph P. Eagerton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of the State of Ala-
bama. Argued by Mr. Rae M. Crowe for the Appellants in No. 81-1268,
by Mr. C. B. Arendall, Jr. for the appellants in No. 81–1020, and by Mr.
John J. Breckenridge for the appellees in both cases.
No. 81-2101. Pennhurst State School and Hospital, et al., Petitioners
v. Terri Lee Halderman, et al. Argued by Mr. H. Bartow Farr, III and
Mr. Allen C. Warshaw for the petitioners and by Mr. David Ferleger
and Mr. Thomas K. Gilhool for the respondents.
No. 81–1893. California, Petitioner v. Marcelino Ramos. Argued by
Mr. Harley D. Mayfield for the petitioner and by Mr. Ezra Hendon for
the respondent.
No. 81-1794. Everett W. Jones, Superintendent, Great Meadow Cor-
rectional Facility, et al., Petitioners v. David Barnes. Argued by Miss
Barbara D. Underwood for the petitioners and by Mrs. Sheila Ginsberg
Riesel for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 81-802. City of Lockhart, Appellant v. United States and Alfred
Cano. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the District Court
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Powell. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Justice White dissents.
No. 81-827. Jefferson County Pharmaceutical Association, Inc., Peti-
tioner v. Abbott Laboratories, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
Stevens join.
No. 81-1181. Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, Petitioner v. United
States, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 81-1180. G. R. Dickerson, Director, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco
and Firearms, Petitioner v. New Banner Institute, Inc. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

416
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1983
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with
whom Justice Brennan, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 81–927. Connecticut, Petitioner v. Lindsay B. Johnson. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Connecticut. Judgment affirmed.
Justice Blackmun announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which Justice Brennan, Justice White, and Justice Mar-
shall joined. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Powell with whom the Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor join.
No. 81-896. Perry Education Association, Appellant v. Perry Local
Education Association, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a pe-
tition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is granted. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall,
Justice Powell, and Justice Stevens join.
No. 81-1203. Moses H. Cone Memorial Hospital, Petitioner v. Mer-
cury Connstruction Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist
with whom the Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 81-2337. John R. Block, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. North Dakota, ex rel. Board of University and School Lands.
Argued by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the petitioners and by Mr. Rob-
ert O. Wefald for the respondents.
No. 82–256. Michigan, Petitioner v. David Kerk Long. Argued by
Mr. Louis J. Caruso for the petitioner, by Mr. David A. Strauss for the
United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr.
James H. Geary for the respondent.
No. 81-1350. United States, Petitioner v. Jose Reynaldo Villamonte-
Marquez, et al. Argued by Mr. Samuel A. Alito, Jr. for the petitioner
and by Mr. Richard P. Ieyoub for the respondents.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1983
417
No. 81-2318. Florida, Petitioner v. Constantino Casal and Omar Gar-
cia. Argued by Ms. Carolyn M. Snurkowski for the petitioner and by
Mr. Arthur F. McCormick for the respondent.
Adjourned until Monday, February 28, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–952. Maryland, et al., Appellants v. United States, et al;
No. 82–953. Tandy Corporation, Appellant v. United States, et al.;
No. 82–992. North American Telephone Association, Appellant v.
United States, et al.; and
No. 82–1001. Illinois, Appellant v. United States, et al. Appeals from
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The judg-
ment is affirmed. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice White join.
No. 82–1175. Norbert R. Berg, etc., Appellant v. Wisconsin, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District IV. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82–1279. Herbert O. Jensen, Appellant v. Winston Satran, War-
den, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82–1296. Lowell M. Stroom, Appellant v. James E. Carter. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–174. H. S. Crocker Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Frank J.
Ostrofe. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Associated General Contractors of California, Inc. v.
California State Council of Carpenters, 459 U.S. - (1983).

420
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1983
No. 82–178. Mitsui & Co., Ltd., et al., Petitioners v. Industrial In-
vestment Development Corporation, et al. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Associated General
Contractors of California, Inc. v. California State Council of Carpen-
ters, 459 U.S. — (1983).

No. 82–999. Chemetron Corporation, Petitioner v. Business Funds,
Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Herman & MacLean v. Huddleston, 459 U.S.
(1983).

The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is

Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.
No. 82–584. E. W. Jones, Superintendent, Great Meadow Correc-
tional Facility, Petitioner v. Felix Ramirez. The motion of respondent
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
denied.
No. 82–116. Greater Washington Central Labor Council, Petitioner
v. District of Columbia, et al.; and
No. 82-146. Food and Allied Services Trade Council of Metropolitan
Washington, Petitioner v. District of Columbia, et al. The motion of
Greater Washington Board of Trade for leave to intervene as a party
respondent is denied. The alternative request to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals denied.
No. 82-493. Robert C. Bichan, Petitioner v. Chemetron Corporation,
etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun would grant
certiorari, vacate the judgment and remand the case to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consider-
ation in light of Associated General Contractors of California, Inc. v.
California State Council of Carpenters, 459 U.S. (1983).

428
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1983
No. 82-877. Joseph C. Bonanno, Sr., Petitioner v. United States.
The motion of Jack DiFilippi for leave to join in petition for writ of cer-
tiorari is denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 82–959. Florida, Petitioner v. Ken Kilpatrick and Cherie Kilpat-
rick. The motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal
of Florida, First District, denied.
No. 82-1104. General Atomic Company, Petitioner v. United Nuclear
Corporation. The motion of petitioner to substitute GA Technologies,
Inc. as party petitioner is denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of New Mexico denied. Justice Brennan and Justice
Blackmun would grant certiorari.
No. 82-5977. James Douglas Hill, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 82-5987. Herbert Lee Richardson, Petitioner v. Alabama. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Alabama
denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 82-5989. Winford L. Stokes, Petitioner v. Missouri. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri denied. Dissenting
statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 82-5995. James Reed, Jr., Petitioner v. Georgia. The motion of
petitioner to defer consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari is
denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia
denied.

MANDAMUS DENIED

writ of mandamus denied.

OPINION
No. 81-1003. Kevin H. White, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Massachu-
setts Council of Construction Employers, Inc., et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Judicial Court of
Massachusetts for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Black-
mun concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice White
joins.

OPINIONS
No. 81-1802. United States, Petitioner v. Leroy Carlton Knotts. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring
in the judgment with whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan, Jus-
tice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice Stevens con-
curring in the judgment with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall join.
No. 81-554. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Appellant
v. Wyoming, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the District of Wyoming. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
District Court for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Powell with whom Justice O'Connor joins.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
441
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Jus-
tice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by me, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–1098. Isidoro Rodriguez, Appellant v. District of Columbia
Department of Employment Services. Appeal from the District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82-6054. Gilbert Williams Becker, Appellant v. Robert E.
Doran, Superintendent, California Rehabilitation Center. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the ap-
peal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-664. Linda Sidoti Palmore, Applicant v. Anthony J. Sidoti.
The application to stay the mandate of the District Court of Appeals of
Florida, Second District, addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to
the Court is denied. Justice Stevens would grant the application.
No. A-678. Frederick Walker, Applicant v. United States. The appli-
cation for stay addressed to Justice Rehnquist and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A–679. Larry E. Cadle, Applicant v. United States. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Rehnquist and referred to the Court
is denied.
No. A-690. Hayfield Northern Railroad Company, Inc. and Minne-
sota, Applicants v. Chicago, Northwestern Transportation Company.
The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. A-691. In Re D. L. Carter, et al., Applicants. The application for
stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-707. Paul V. Watson and Sharon E. Watson, Applicants v.

442
MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
United States and Internal Revenue Service Agent, David L. Ackley.
The application for stay addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. D-324. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marvin R. Javitz. It is
ordered that Marvin R. Javitz, of Brooklyn, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-325. In the Matter of Disbarment of A. James Hampares. It is
ordered that A. James Hampares, of New York, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-326. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Michael Galloway. It
is ordered that John Michael Galloway, of Anderson, South Carolina, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-327. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry J. Stevens, Jr.. It
is ordered that Harry J. Stevens, Jr., of Allenhurst, New Jersey, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-328. In the Matter of Disbarment of Martin Edward Juncker.
It is ordered that Martin Edward Juncker, of St. Louis, Missouri, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-329. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Anthony White. It is
ordered that Paul Anthony White, of Gladstone, Missouri, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 93, Original. State of Oklahoma, Plaintiff v. State of Arkansas,
et al. The motion of Illinois and Tennessee for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted. The motion for leave to file a bill of complaint is
denied.
No. 82-65. Margaret R. Brown, et al., Appellants v. Thyra Thomson,
Secretary of State of Wyoming, et al. The motion of appellees James L.
Thompson, et al. for divided argument is denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
443
No. 82-118. Crown, Cork & Seal Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Theo-
dore Parker. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied.
No. 82-524. Baltimore Gas and Electric Co., et al., Petitioners v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc.;
No. 82–545. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 82-551. Commonwealth Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al. The motion of petition-
ers in No. 82-551 for divided argument is denied. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 82-914. Monsanto Company, Petitioner v. Spray-Rite Service
Corporation. The motion of Washington, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae, out-of-time, is denied. Justice White took no part in the
consideration or decision of this motion.

In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

OPINIONS
No. 81-485. Hillsboro National Bank, Petitioner v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit; and
No. 81–930. United States, Petitioner v. Bliss Dairy, Inc. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment in No. 81-485 is reversed and case remanded to Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings with the opinion of this Court. Judgment
in No. 81-930 is reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.

452
MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan in
No. 81-485. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Marshall
joins, concurring in the judgment in No. 81-485 and dissenting in No.
81-930. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 81-1404. Carlisle W. Briscoe, Chris P. Vickers, Sr., and James
N. Ballard, Petitioners v. Martin Lahue and James W. Hunley, etc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall
with whom Justice Blackmun joins except as to Part I. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 81-773. North Dakota, Appellant v. United States. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice O'Connor
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Rehnquist
joins.
No. 81–1494. John R. Block, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Onilea Neal. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Marshall. The Chief Justice concurs in the judgment.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
459
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–1192. Diane DiPiero, Appellant v. Allen Goodman and Mi-
chael Rudy. Appeal from the Appeals Court of Massachusetts. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1531. Montana, Petitioner v. Robert Charles Jackson. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Montana. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Montana to consider whether
its judgment is based upon federal or state constitutional grounds, or
both, California v. Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972), and, if its judgment is
not based upon state constitutional grounds, for further consideration
in light of South Dakota v. Neville, 459 U.S. (1983). Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-704. George Barone, et al., Applicants v. United States. The
application for recall and stay of mandate addressed to Justice Marshall
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-728. Daily Local News Company, Applicant v. Robert S.
Gawthrop, III, Judge, Court of Common Pleas, Chester County, Penn-
sylvania, et al.; and
No. A-729. Philadelphia Newspapers, Inc., Applicant v. Robert S.
Gawthrop, III, Judge, Court of Common Pleas, Chester County, Penn-
sylvania, et al. The orders heretofore entered by Justice Brennan on
March 3, 1983, are vacated and the applications for stay are denied.

460
MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
No. A-771. James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Appli-
cants v. Community for Creative Non-Violence, et al. The order hereto-
fore entered by the Chief Justice on March 17, 1983, is continued pend-
ing the timely filing and disposition of a petition for writ of certiorari.
No. D-278. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank A. Paglianite. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-303. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sheldon P. Otis. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-315. In the Matter of Disbarment of James L. Coburn. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-320. In the Matter of Disbarment of J. Mortimer Rubenstein.
J. Mortimer Rubenstein, of Cliffside Park, New Jersey, having re-
quested to resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered
that his name be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice
before the Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore is-
sued on February 28, 1983, is hereby discharged.
No. 81-984. First National City Bank, Petitioner v. Banco Para El
Comercio Exterior De Cuba. The motion of the Solicitor General to per-
mit Richard G. Wilkins, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice
on behalf of the United States as amicus curiae is granted. .
No. 81-1271. Falls City Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Vanco Bever-
age, Inc. The motion of respondent for leave to file second supplemental
brief after argument is denied.
No. 81-2386. Philip Del Costello, Petitioner v. International Broth-
erhood of Teamsters, et al. The motion of respondent Anchor Motor
Freight, Inc. for special permission to divide oral argument is denied.
No. 82-242. Anne McGill Burford, Administrator, Environmental
Protection Agency, Petitioner v. Sierra Club, et al. The motion of re-
spondent Environmental Defense Fund for reconsideration of order of
February 22, 1983, denying leave to file motion for divided argument,
out-of-time, is denied.
No. 82-357. Michigan, Petitioner v. Raymond Clifford and Emma
Jean Clifford. The motion of Timothy A. Baughman, Esquire, to permit
Janice M. Joyce Bartee, Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice
on behalf of petitioner is granted. The application of petitioner for leave
to file a brief in excess of the page limitations presented to Justice
O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is denied.
No. 82-432. Local No. 82, Furniture and Piano Moving, Furniture
Store Drivers, Helpers, Warehousemen and Packers, et al., Petitioners
v. Jerome Crowley, et al. The motion of respondents to limit questions
presented for review and/or to dismiss the writ as improvidently
granted is denied.

MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
461
No. 82-486. United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of Amer-
ica, Local 610, AFL-CIO, et al., Petitioners v. Paul E. Scott, et al. The
motion of National Right to Work Legal Defense Foundation for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 82-502. Pallas Shipping Agency, Ltd., Petitioner v. Joseph
Duris. The motion of Local 1291, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici
curiae is granted.
No. 82-524. Baltimore Gas and Electric Co., et al., Petitioners v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc.;
No. 82-545. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 82-551. Commonwealth Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al. The motion of Limerick
Ecology Action, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this motion.
No. 82–647. Donald J. Kirkpatrick, Petitioner v. Christian Homes of
Abilene, Inc., et al. The motion of petitioner to direct the Clerk to
schedule oral argument during April, 1983 is granted.
No. 82-660. United States, Petitioner v. Harrison P. Cronic. The mo-
tion of respondent to discharge counsel appointed by lower court and
for leave to proceed pro se is denied. The motion for appointment of
counsel is granted and it is ordered that David W. Duncan, Esquire, of
Durango, Colorado, is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent
in this case.
No. 82–1041. Esther C. Dickman, et al., Petitioners v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue. The motion of the parties to dispense with print-
ing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 82–1066. United States, Appellant v. Harry Ptasynski, et al. The
motion of the Solicitor General to direct the Clerk to schedule oral argu-
ment during April, 1983 is granted.
No. 82-1135. W. J. Estelle, Jr., Director, Texas Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Carl Edwin Wiggins. The motion of respondent
for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Craig
Smyser, Esquire, of Houston, Texas, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the of respondent in this case. In all other respects the motion is
denied.
No. 82-1156. Teledyne Movible Offshore, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Dan Thompson. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.

462
MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
No. 82-1253. Herman S. Solem, Warden, South Dakota State Peni-
tentiary, and Mark V. Meierhenry, Attorney General of South Dakota,
Petitioners v. John Bartlett. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 82–1260. Copperweld Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Indepen-
dence Tube Corporation. The motion of petitioners to suggest that the
Court invite the Solicitor General to present the views of the United
States is denied. The motion of American Iron and Steel Institute for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of National
Association of Manufacturers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of the United States for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States. Justice White took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions and order.
No. 82-6077. In Re Joseph D. Williams, Petitioner. The motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. The petitioner
is allowed until April 11, 1983, in which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33
of the Rules of this Court.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 82–1050. Margaret H. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Appellant v. Robert H. Mathews, et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama. In
this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

State Lands Commission and City of Los Angeles. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of California granted.
No. 82-1095. R. Pulley, Warden, Petitioner v. Robert Alton Harris.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.

writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied. Justice

of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York denied.

The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice Brennan and Justice Mar-
shall would grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and vacate the
conviction.

tioner v. Walter S. Blume, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. The Chief
Justice and Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.

ment of Public Welfare, et al., Petitioners v. Evangeline Coleman, et
al. The motion of respondent Coleman for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi denied. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.

MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
473
No. 82-6019. Robert Alton Harris, Petitioner v. R. Pulley, Warden.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

Justice Marshall.

tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Eastern
Division, denied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice
Marshall.
No. 82-6145. Elmo C. Tatum, Petitioner v. Regents of the Univer-
sity of Nebraska-Lincoln, et al. The petitioner is directed to file a re-
sponse to the motion of respondent for damages within thirty days. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 82-6134. In Re James David Morrow, Petitioner. The petition for
writ of mandamus is denied.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 82-6060. In Re Jim Green, Petitioner. The petition for a writ of
prohibition and/or mandamus is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 82-764. Charlotte L. White, et vir, Petitioners v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue;
No. 82-5528. Janice Buttrum, Petitioner v. Georgia; and
No. 82-5793. Jimmy Lee Horton, Petitioner v. Georgia. The petitions
for rehearing are denied.

No. 82-5524. H. J. Jones, Petitioner v. W. J. Estelle, Director,

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 82-65. Margaret R. Brown, et al., Appellants v. Thyra Thomson,
Secretary of State of Wyoming, et al. Argued by Ms. Suellen L. David-
son for the appellants and by Mr. Randall T. Cox for the respondents,
pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 81-1891. Morrison-Knudsen Construction Company, et al., Peti-

482
Applicant
MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
City and State
Movant
tioners v. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation, United States
Department of Labor, et al. Argued by Mr. Arthur Larson for the peti-
tioners, by Mr. Alan I. Horowitz for the federal respondent supporting
petitioners and by Mr. Geo. Stephen Leonard for respondent Hilyer.
No. 82–276. Raymond L. Dirks, Petitioner v. Securities and Ex-
change Commission. Argued by Mr. David Bonderman for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Paul Gonson for the respondent.
No. 82-401. Baxter Rice, individually and as Director of the De-
partment of Alcoholic Beverage Control of California, Petitioner v.
Eva Rehner. Argued by Mr. Alan S. Meth for the petitioner, by Mr.
Stephen V. Quesenberry for the respondent, and by Mr. Joshua I.
Schwartz for the United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of
Court.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

TUESDAY, MARCH 22, 1983
483
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 81–1222. United States, Petitioner v. Generix Drug Corporation,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81-1271. Falls City, Industries, Inc., Petitioner v. Vanco Bever-
age, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.

OPINIONS
No. 80-2146. Florida, Petitioner v. Mark Royer. On writ of certiorari
to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District. Judgment af-
firmed. Justice White announced the judgment of the Court and deliv-
ered an opinion in which Justice Marshall, Justice Powell and Justice
Stevens joined. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell. Opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan concurring in the result. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom the
Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 81-1335. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, et al., Petition-
ers v. Marc Feldman and Edward J. Hickey, Jr. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of Columbia for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor;
Jim Jones, Attorney General; Jerry M. Conley, Director, Department
of Fish and Game, Plaintiffs v. States of Oregon and Washington. Ar-
gued by Mr. Jim Jones for the plaintiffs and by Mr. Edward B. Mackie
for the defendant State of Washington.

486
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 23, 1983
No. 82-271. Carlos Chardon, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Juan Fumero
Soto, et al. Argued by Mr. John DeGooyer for the petitioners and by
Mr. Sheldon Nahmod for the respondents.
No. 81-2147. Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. San Carlos Apache Tribe
of Arizona, et al.; and Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. Navajo Tribe of
Indians, et al.; and
No. 81-2188. Montana, et al., Petitioners v. Northern Cheyenne
Tribe of the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation, et al. One hour
and thirty minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Jon L.
Kyl for the petitioners in No. 81-2147, by Mr. Michael T. Greely for the
petitioners in No. 81–2188, by Mr. Robert S. Pelcyger for the respond-
ent Montana Indian Tribes, by Mr. Simon H. Rifkind for the respond-
ent Arizona Indian Tribes, and by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the re-
spondent United States.
Adjourned until Monday, March 28, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1983
487
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 82-713. Thurston Motor Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Jordan K.
Rand, Ltd. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-901. Leon W. Knight, et al., Appellants v. Minnesota Com-
munity College Faculty Association, et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Minnesota. The judgment is
affirmed.
No. 82–1269. Lloyd L. Fink, Appellant v. Board of Education of War-
ren County Schools. Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsyl-
vania. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-309. In the Matter of Disbarment of Oliver Barr McClellan.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-316. In the Matter of Disbarment of H. Reed Harris. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-330. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Jacob Bluestein.
It is ordered that William Jacob Bluestein, of Los Angeles, California,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 82–185. Boston Firefighters Union, Local 718, Petitioner v. Bos-
ton Chapter, NAACP, et al.;

488
MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1983
No. 82-246. Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, Inc., Petitioner
v. Pedro Castro, et al.; and
No. 82–259. Nancy B. Beecher, et al., Petitioners v. Boston Chapter,
NAACP, et al. The motion of American Jewish Congress for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. Justice Marshall took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 82-486. United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of Amer-
ica, Local 610, AFL-CIO, et al., Petitioners v. Paul E. Scott, et al. The
motion of Associated Builders & Contractors, Inc. for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Legal Foundation of
America for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 82–695. Franchise Tax Board of the State of California, Appel-
lant v. Construction Laborers Vacation Trust for Southern California,
et al. The motion of American Federation of Labor and Congress of In-
dustrial Organizations for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 82–713. Thurston Motor Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Jordan K.
Rand, Ltd. The motion to substitute Blackburn Truck Lines, Inc. as
party petitioner in place of Thurston Motor Lines, Inc. is denied with-
out prejudice to consideration of the motion by the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on remand.
No. 82-940. Elizabeth Anderson Hishon, Petitioner v. King and Spal-
ding. The motion of the parties to unseal the record is granted.
No. 82-973. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Predrag Stevic. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 82-6368. James Franklin Rose, Petitioner v. Florida. The appli-
cation for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the Court
is denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 82-898. Minnesota State Board for Community Colleges, et al.,
Appellants v. Leon W. Knight, et al.; and
No. 82-977. Minnesota Community College Faculty Association, et
al., Appellants v. Leon W. Knight, et al. Appeals from the United
States District Court for the District of Minnesota. In these cases prob-
able jurisdiction is noted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one
hour is allotted for oral argument.

ORAL ARGUMENT

OPINIONS
No. 81-1839. Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company, Appellant v.
Minnesota Commissioner of Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Minnesota. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Justice Blackmun joins this opin-
ion except footnote 12. Opinion by Justice White concurring in part and
dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
No. 81–1114. Illinois, Petitioner v. Abbott & Associates, Inc., et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 81-969. Washington, et al., Appellants v. United States. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice White, Justice Marshall, and Justice Stevens join.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 82-372. Federal Trade Commission, et al., Petitioners v. Grolier
Incorporated. Argued by Mr. Kenneth S. Geller for the petitioners and
by Mr. Daniel S. Mason for the respondent.

OPINIONS
No. 81-6756. Melvin E. Tuten, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Plaintiff v. State of California, et
al. On Exceptions to Special Master's Report, Recommended Decree
and motions to intervene. The motions of Indian Tribes for leave to in-
tervene granted. The joint motion for entry of supplemental decree
granted. Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master sustained in
part and overruled in part. Parties are directed to submit a proposed
decree before September 19, 1983. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion
by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens
join concurring in part and dissenting in part. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1983
503
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-927. Francis X. Bellotti, Attorney General of Massachusetts,
Appellant v. Michael J. Connolly, et al.; and
No. 82-936. Frederick C. Langone, et al., Appellants v. Michael J.
Connolly, et al. Appeals from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachu-
setts. The appeals are dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeals were taken as petitions for writs of certio-
rari, certiorari is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 82–1093. Luke William Able, Jr., etc., Appellant v. Texas, et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Texas, First Supreme Judicial Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 82-6238. Hurie Jones, et al., Appellants v. John Mitchell, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82–6239. Joycelyn M. Jones, et al., Appellants v. Jefferson Par-
ish School Board. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82–1153. Motor Club of America Insurance Company, Appellant
v. New Jersey, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-1281. Shelly & Sands, Inc., et al., Appellants v. Pennsylvania
Department of Transportation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Pennsylvania, Western District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.

504
MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1983
No. 82-6203. Alex Wakeman and Walter Ten Fingers, Appellants v.
South Dakota. Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Dakota. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1278. Billie Denise Williams, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Florida v. Royer, 460 U.S. (1983).
No. 82–397. State Bar of Texas, Petitioner v. Charles Ben Howell.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light
of District of Columbia Court of Appeals v. Feldman, 460 U.S.
(1983).
No. 82-1360. John W. Cross, et al., Petitioners v. Lloyd Baxter, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit (former Fifth Circuit). The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act
of 1965, 42 U.S.C. 1973, as amended in 1982.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. Ralph Bouma, et ux., Petitioner v. Larry C. Iverson, Inc.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted.
No. A-725. Yvonne W. Cavanaugh, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-311. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Ebaugh Mason,
Jr.. Disbarment entered.
No. D-312. In the Matter of Disbarment of John William Ergazos.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-331. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brian Alan Bishop. It is
ordered that Brian Alan Bishop, of Nevada City, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

of Arizona, et al.; and Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. Navajo Tribe of

file a response to the supplemental brief, after argument, is granted.

ica, Local 610, AFL-CIO, et al., Petitioners v. Paul E. Scott, et al. The

amicus curiae is granted.

argument is denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1983
No. 82–1325. I.A.M. National Pension Fund, Petitioner v. Madge H.
Elser, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 82-6080. Thomas A. Barefoot, Petitioner v. W. J. Estelle, Jr.,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of petitioner
for divided argument to permit NAACP Legal Defense and Educa-
tional Fund, Inc. to present oral argument as amicus curiae is granted.
The application of counsel for the petitioner to stay further proceedings
in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, case No.
82-1680, pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court pre-
sented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is granted.
The request for a stay of further proceedings in the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Western District of Texas is denied.
No. 82-6208. Clovis Carl Green, Jr., Petitioner v. Carl White, Super-
intendent, Missouri Training Center for Men, etc. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. The petitioner
is allowed until April 25, 1983, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33 of the Rules of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 82-1273. Maine, Petitioner v. Richard Thornton. The motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine granted.
The case is consolidated with No. 82–15, Oliver v. United States, and a
total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

OPINIONS
Movant
Bennett H.
Brummer
No. 81-1675. Frank Kush, et al., Petitioners v. Kevin Rutledge. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81–1044. United States Postal Service Board of Governors, Peti-
tioner v. Louis H. Aikens. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of Columbia for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Justice Marshall
concurs in the judgment. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun with
whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 81-1664. Metropolitan Edison Company, Petitioner v. National
Labor Relations Board, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Powell.
No. 81–1574. Local 926, International Union of Operating Engineers,
AFL-CIO, et al., Appellants v. Robert C. Jones. Appeal from the
Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari is granted. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not inconsis-
tent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Powell and Justice
O'Connor join.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, APRIL 12, 1983
521
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-647. Donald J. Kirkpatrick, Petitioner v. Christian Homes of
Abilene, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Texas, Eleventh Supreme Judicial District. The Court has considered
the memorandum filed by petitioner in response to the representations
of the State of Texas in its brief before this Court which bring to light a
question of state law not passed upon or relied upon below. The resolu-
tion of this question may establish that petitioner is entitled to the relief
he seeks as a matter of Texas statutory law. If this is so, a decision of
the constitutional question on which we granted certiorari would be un-
necessary. See Paschall v. Christie-Stewart, 414 U.S. 100 (1973);
Musser v. Utah, 333 U.S. 95 (1948). Accordingly, the judgment of the
Court of Appeals of Texas, Eleventh Supreme Judicial District, is va-
cated and the case is remanded to that Court for further proceedings to
determine whether, under Texas law, petitioner could have obtained
and may still obtain a decree designating him as the father of
his child pursuant to the provisions of Texas Family Code Sections
13.01-13.09. The Clerk is directed to issue the mandate forthwith.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 82-486. United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of Amer-
ca, Local 610, AFL-CIO, et al., Petitioners v. Paul E. Scott, et al. This
case is hereby scheduled for argument on April 26, 1983, in place of No.
82-647, Donald J. Kirkpatrick v. Christian Homes of Abilene, Inc.,
et al.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1983
523
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-905. Sooner Federal Savings and Loan Association, et al.,
Appellants v. Oklahoma Tax Commission, et al. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 82-1382. Walter Tolub, et al., Appellants v. Herbert B. Evans,
as Chief Administrative Judge of the State of New York, et al. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82–1420. Emily Sanford and Jackie Sanford, Appellants v. Daisy
E. Dumas. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 82-983. James E. Duncan, Appellant v. Harold Peck. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton County. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal
was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82–1237. Carmela M. Stella, Appellant v. Mercy Hospital, et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82-6249. Gilbert G. Velilla, Appellant v. UTC/Hamilton Stand-
ard Division, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Connecticut. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82-1243. Richard D. Bunker, Appellant v. National Gypsum
Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice Brennan
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

524
MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1983
No. 82–1293. Jeremiah Temple, et al., Appellants v. Alabama Public
Service Commission, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Ala-
bama. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 82–1386. Tom Fields, Appellant v. Summit Engineering. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a properly presented federal question.
No. 82–1445. The Don't Bankrupt Washington Committee, Appellant
v. Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, et
al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction it appearing appel-
lant lacks standing to bring this appeal.
No. 82-1477. Pacific Standard Life Insurance Company and Graham
Beach Partners, Appellants v. Committee to Save Nukolii, et al. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The motion of National Associ-
ation of Home Builders, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of National Association of Realtors for leave to file
a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 82-6257. George R. Fulk, et al., Appellants v. Timothy B. Mo-
ritz, M.D., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Ohio. The motion of appellant for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis is granted. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Ste-
vens and Justice O'Connor would dismiss the appeal for want of juris-
diction, treat the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari and deny certiorari.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-25. Albert A. Jones, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Margaret H.
Heckler, Secretary, Department of Health and Human Services. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Miss. Code Ann. Section 91-1-15 (Cum. Supp.
1982), as to the Jones petitioners, and in light of Adkins v.
McEldowney, 280 S.E. 2d 231 (1981), as to the Simms petitioners.
No. 82-1399. Donald A. Alessi and John P. Bartolomei, Petitioners v.
Committee on Professional Standards, Third Judicial Department. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New York. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further
consideration in light of In Re R. M. J., 455 U.S. 191 (1982).

MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1983
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
525
No. D-319. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan Jerome Feder. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-327. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry J. Stevens, Jr..
Harry J. Stevens, Jr., of Short Hills, New Jersey, having requested to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on March
7, 1983, is hereby discharged.
No. D-332. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward Parsons. It is
ordered that Edward Parsons, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81-2332. Norfolk Redevelopment and Housing Authority, etc. v.
Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia, et al. The
motion of National Institute of Municipal Law Officers for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of United States Confer-
ence of Mayors, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions.
No. 82–91. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v. Pa-
dungsri Phinpathya. The motion of respondent to enlarge record, sug-
gestion of mootness and motion to stay further proceedings pending ad-
ministrative action is denied.
No. 82-585. Aloha Airlines, Inc., Appellant v. Director of Taxation of
Hawaii; and
No. 82-586. Hawaiian Airlines, Inc., Appellant v. Director of Tax-
ation of Hawaii. The motion of appellee for divided argument is denied.
No. 82-862. Consolidated Rail Corporation, Petitioner v. Thomas
LeStrange. The motion to substitute Lee Ann LeStrange Darrone, as
Administratrix of Estate of Thomas LeStrange, in place of respondent
Thomas LeStrange, deceased, is granted.
No. 82-6080. Thomas A. Barefoot, Petitioner v. W. J. Estelle, Jr.,
Director, Texas Department of Corrections. The motion of Washington
Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
The motion of Florida for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae and for additional time for argument is denied.

HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 82-6472. In Re Robert E. Lipscomb, Petitioner. Petition for writ
of habeas corpus denied.
MANDAMUS Denied

of mandamus denied.

OPINIONS
No. 81-1273. Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General of the
United States, et al., Petitioners v. Merck & Co., Inc.; and
No. 81-1472. Merck & Co., Inc., Petitioner v. Charles A. Bowsher,
Comptroller General of the United States and United States. On writs.
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Opinion by Justice White concurring in part and dissenting in part with
whom Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Stevens joins.
No. 81-1635. John B. Anderson, et al., Petitioners v. Anthony J. Cel-
ebrezze, Jr., Secretary of State of Ohio. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice
White, Justice Powell, and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 81-419. Texas, Petitioner v. Clifford James Brown. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice
Rehnquist announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opin-
ion in which the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice O'Connor
join. Concurring opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Powell
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Opinion
by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Brennan and Justice Marshall join.

552
TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1983
No. 81-1120. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Richard W.
Rylander, Sr., as President of Rylander & Co. Realtors, Inc., et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81-2399. Metropolitan Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
People Against Nuclear Energy, et al.; and
No. 82-358. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. People Against Nuclear Energy, et al. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
with instructions to dismiss the petition for review. Opinion by Justice
Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan.

FRIDAY, APRIL 22, 1983
555
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. A-858. Alabama, Applicant v. John Louis Evans, III. On applica-
tion of Alabama to dissolve and vacate the stay ordered by the United
States District Court for the Southern District of Alabama. The appli-
cation is granted. Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by the Chief
Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall. Justice Brennan would
deny the application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1983
557
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-6444. Lawrence Ray, Appellant v. Department of the Navy,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No.
-
ORDERS IN Pending CaSES
Robert B. Sampson, Petitioner v. Committee on Proba-
tion. The motion to direct the Clerk to file the petition for writ of certio-
rari out-of-time is denied.
-
No. . Boland and Cornelius, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Chesa-
peake and Ohio Railway Co., et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file
the petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
No. A-843. Carlos Marcello and Charles E. Roemer, II, Applicants v.
United States. The application to recall and stay the mandate of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit addressed to Jus-
tice Brennan and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-288. In the Matter of Disbarment of Sidney Z. Lieberman.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-296. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick L. Coleman,
Jr. Disbarment entered.
No. D-301. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robbin James Bonnin.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-308. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick Richard Oden-
dahl. Disbarment entered.
No. D-313. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert A. Grimes. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-322. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard W. Minn. How-
ard W. Minn, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as

558
MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1983
a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on February
28, 1983, is hereby discharged.
No. D-333. In the Matter of Disbarment of Herbert Russell Baxter.
It is ordered that Herbert Russell Baxter, of Mentor, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-334. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence M. Aglow. It is
ordered that Lawrence M. Aglow, of West Chester, Pennsylvania, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-335. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald G. Huber. It is
ordered that Donald G. Huber, of Okemos, Michigan, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-336. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lee Marshall McLean. It
is ordered that Lee Marshall McLean, of Washington, D. C., be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-337. In the Matter of Disbarment of Edward B. Vandoren. It
is ordered that Edward B. Vandoren, of Los Angeles, California, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

for the respondents in 81-2386, and by Mr. Isaac N. Groner for the re-
spondents in 81-2408.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
ORDER
Ordered:
1. That the rules of procedure in bankruptcy cases, recommended by

MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1983
570
the Judicial Conference of the United States, and to be known as the
Banktruptcy Rules, be, and they hereby are, prescribed pursuant to
Section 2075, Title 28, United States Code, to govern the practice and
procedure in cases under Title 11, United States Code.
2. That the aforementioned Bankruptcy Rules shall take effect on
August 1, 1983, and shall be applicable to proceedings than pending, ex-
cept to the extent that in the opinion of the court their application in a
pending proceeding would not be feasible or would work injustice, in
which event the former procedure applies.
3. That the Bankruptcy Rules, heretofore prescribed by this Court,
be, and they hereby are, superseded by the new rules, effective August
1, 1983.
4. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
these new Bankruptcy Rules to the Congress in accordance with the
provisions of Section 2075 of Title 28, United States Code.

(JOURNAL)

OPINION
No. 81-1581. Antone Olim, et al., Petitioners v. Delbert Kaahanui
Wakinekona. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Brennan joins and with whom
Justice Stevens joins as to Part I.

OPINION
No. 81-2150. Jim McNeff, Inc., Petitioner v. Frank L. Todd, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 82-5576. Jeffrey Lee Pickett, etc., et al., Appellants v. Braxton
Brown, et al. Argued by Mr. Harold W. Horne for the appellants and
by Ms. Susan Short for the appellees.
No. 82–411. Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company,
Petitioner v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Argued by
Mr. Andrew M. Kramer for the petitioner and by Mrs. Harriet S.
Shapiro for the respondent.
No. 82–1066. United States, Appellant v. Harry Ptasynski, et al.
Argued by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the appellant and by Mr.
Stephen F. Williams for the appellees.
No. 81-2245. Nevada, Petitioner v. United States, et al.;
No. 81-2276. Truckee-Carson Irrigation District, Petitioner v.
United States, et al.; and

574
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 27, 1983
No. 82-38. Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe of Indians, Petitioner v.
Truckee-Carson Irrigation District, et al. Argued by Mr. E. Barrett
Prettyman, Jr. for the State of Nevada, by Mr. Frederick G. Girard
for the Truckee-Carson Irrigation District, by Mr. Robert S. Pelcyger
for the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe of Indians, and by Mr. Edwin S.
Kneedler for the United States.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, APRIL 28, 1983
575
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
ORDERS
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein new Rules 11(h), 12(i) and 12.2(e), and amendments to Rules
6(e) and (g), 11(a), 12.2(b), (c) and (d), 16(a), 23(b), 32(a), (c) and (d),
35(b) and 55.
2. That Rule 58 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure and the
Appendix of Forms are hereby abrogated.
3. That the foregoing additions and amendments to the Federal
Rules of Criminal Procedure, together with the abrogation of Rule 58
and the Official Forms, shall take effect on August 1, 1983 and shall
govern all criminal proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, in proceedings then pending.
4. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing additions to and changes in accordance
with the provisions of Sections 3771 and 3772 of Title 18, United States
Code. Dissenting statement by Justice O'Connor.
Ordered:
1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure be, and they hereby
are, amended by including therein new Rules 26(g), 53(f), 72 through 76
and new Official Forms 33 and 34, and amendments to Rules 6(b), 7(b),
11, 16, 26(a) and (b), 52(a), 53(a), (b) and (c) and 67.
2. That the foregoing additions and amendments to the Federal
Rules of Civil Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1983 and shall
govern all civil proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, in proceedings then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing additions to and changes in the Federal
Rules of Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2072 of Title 28, United States Code.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 2, 1983
577
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and Justice
O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-540. Mississippi, Appellant v. William French Smith, Attor-
ney General of the United States. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Columbia. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 82-1141. Common Cause, et al., Appellants v. William F. Bolger,
Postmaster General, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Columbia. The judgment is affirmed. Justice
Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens would note probable ju-
risdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 82–1513. Escambia River Electric Cooperative, Inc., Appellant
v. Florida Public Service Commission, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 82–1555. Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission, et al., Appel-
lants v. Consolidated Rail Corporation. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 82-6419. Thomas Robert Lacher, Appellant v. City of Bemidji.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81–1063. United States, et al., Petitioners v. George W. Meeks,
as President, St. George Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of United States v. Rylander, 460 U.S.
(1983).

578
No.
MONDAY, MAY 2, 1983
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
. In the Matter of Julius Stern. The application for reinstate-
ment as a member of the Bar of this Court is denied.
No. 80-1640. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Steven Sholly, et al.; and
No. 80-1656. Metropolitan Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.
People Against Nuclear Energy, et al. The motion of respondents to
retax costs is denied. Justice White and Justice Blackmun would grant
this motion.
No. 81-2245. Nevada, Petitioner v. United States, et al.;
No. 81-2276. Truckee-Carson Irrigation District, Petitioner v.
United States, et al.; and
No. 82–38. Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe of Indians, Petitioner v.
Truckee-Carson Irrigation District, et al. The motion of Pyramid Lake
Paiute Tribe of Indians for leave to file reply brief out-of-time is
granted.

of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
granted.

Tenth Circuit denied. The Chief Justice, Justice Blackmun and Justice

of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.

for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Dis-

MONDAY, MAY 2, 1983
No. 82–1512. AAA Liquors, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Joseph E.
Seagram and Sons, Inc., etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit denied. Justice Brennan took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
No. 82–6106. Mack Arthur King, Petitioner v. Mississippi. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi denied. Dis-
senting statement by Justice Brennan. Dissenting statement by Justice
Marshall.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 82-6354. In Re Iverison Broadway, Petitioner. Petition for writ
of mandamus denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 82-6060. In Re Jim Green, Petitioner;
No. 82-6084. Harlan D. Thrasher, Petitioner v. Missouri State High-
way Commission, et al.; and
No. 82-6144. Debra Melanie Udell, Petitioner v. University of Low-
ell, et al. Petitions for rehearing are denied.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Stew-
art (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on May 11, 1983, and for such further
time as may be required to complete unfinished business, pursuant to
28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered entered on the minutes of this Court,
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.
