MONDAY, MAY 2, 1983
OPINIONS
No. 81-1320. William Kolender, et al., Appellants v. Edward
Lawson. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Rehnquist
joins.
No. 81-857. Oralia Martinez, as Next Friend of Roberto Morales, Pe-
titioner v. Raymon L. Bynum, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Justice Bren-
nan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81-1536. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. John
F. Tufts, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion
by Justice O'Connor.
No. 81-2337. John R. Block, Secretary of Agriculture, et al., Peti-
tioners v. North Dakota, ex rel. Board of University and School Lands;
and
No. 82–132. North Dakota, ex rel. Board of University and School
Lands, Petitioner v. John R. Block, Secretary of Agriculture, et al. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari granted and case consolidated with No.
81-2337. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice White and announced by the Chief
Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor.
☑
Adjourned until Monday, May 16, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 16, 1983
593
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82–233. Owen H. Brooks, et al., Appellants v. William F. Win-
ter, Governor of Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 82-413. William F. Winter, Governor of Mississippi, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Owen H. Brooks, et al. Appeals from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of Mississippi. The judgment and
order are vacated and the cases are remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Northern District of Mississippi for further consider-
ation in light of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, 42 U.S.C.
Section 1973, as amended in 1982.
No. 82-1436. City of Torrance, Appellant v. Workers' Compensation
Appeals Board of California, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
California. The motion of California Workers' Compensation Institute
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-1558. Norman C. Gagnon and Philip C. Chouinard, Appel-
lants v. Massachusetts. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of
Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari is denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Leo M. Mullen, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file the petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time is
denied.
No. A-824. James Ervin Boyd, Applicant v. United States. The ap-
plication for stay addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-869. Myles E. Billups, Sr., Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay and/or bond addressed to Justice Powell and re-
ferred to the Court is denied.

594
MONDAY, MAY 16, 1983
No. A-882. Marsha Hollander, as Administratrix of the Estate of
Carrie Hollander, Deceased, Applicant v. University of Rochester, et
al. The application for leave to dispense with printing the petition for a
writ of certiorari presented to Justice Marshall and by him referred to
the Court is denied.
No. D-309. In the Matter of Disbarment of Oliver Barr McClellan.
The motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing is denied.
No. D-310. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frank Sheridan Tilyou,
Jr. Disbarment entered.
No. D-314. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gale Sanders Molovinsky.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-325. In the Matter of Disbarment of A. James Hampares. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-326. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Michael Galloway.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-329. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Anthony White. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-338. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Sellers Collins. It is
ordered that John Sellers Collins, of Glen Burnie, Maryland, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-339. In the Matter of Disbarment of Carl Leibowitz. It is or-
dered that Carl Leibowitz, of South Bend, Indiana, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-340. In the Matter of Disbarment of John D. Long, III. It is
ordered that John D. Long, III, of Union, South Carolina, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81-2159. Bill M. Silkwood, Administrator of the Estate of Karen
G. Silkwood, Deceased, Appellant v. Kerr-McGee Corporation, etc., et
al. The motion of National Women's Health Network for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of New Jersey Depart-
ment of Public Advocate for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 81-2245. Nevada, Petitioner v. United States, et al.;

MONDAY, MAY 16, 1983
595
No. 81-2276. Truckee-Carson Irrigation District, Petitioner v.
United States, et al.; and
No. 82–38. Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe of Indians, Petitioner v.

General for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.

Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia, et al. The
motion of Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

al. The motion of respondents for divided argument and for additional
time for oral argument is denied.

Court of California, Riverside County. The motion of respondent for di-
vided argument and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 82–799. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, Petitioner v.
Federal Labor Relations Authority, et al. The motion of respondent
National Treasury Employees Union for divided argument is denied.
No. 82–827. Minnesota, Petitioner v. Marshall Donald Murphy. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument
as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.

and Donna Marie Jacobsen. The motion of Americans for Effective Law
Enforcement, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted.

tioners v. Martin Fox. The motion of Investment Company Institute for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 82-1273. Maine, Petitioner v. Richard Thornton. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Donna L.
Zeegers, Esquire, of Augusta, Maine, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the respondent in this case.

tioners v. Goodpasture, Inc. The motion of petitioners to require Advi-
sory Committee on Civil Rules to make available to petitioners pro-
posed amendments to Rules C and E of the Supplemental Rules for
Certain Admiralty & Maritime Claims is denied.

No. 82-1311. Jewell Productions, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Califor-
nia. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Department, Supe-
rior Court of California, County of Los Angeles denied. Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall would grant the petition for a writ of certio-
rari and vacate the conviction.
No. 82–1324. National Farmers' Organization, Inc., Petitioner v. As-
sociated Milk Producers, Inc., et al. The motion of Cooperative League
of the United States of America for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Justice Brennan and Justice
White would grant certiorari. Justice Stevens took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion and this petition.
No. 82-1331. Louisiana Public Service Commission, Petitioner v.
Federal Communications Commission, et al.; and
No. 82-1352. National Association of Regulatory Utility Commission-

608
MONDAY, MAY 16, 1983
ers, et al., Petitioners v. Federal Communications Commission, et al.
The motion of Maryland Office of People's Counsel for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Washington Utilities
and Transportation Commission for leave to file a brief as amicus cu-
riae is granted. The motion of Florida Public Service Commission for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of South
Carolina Department of Consumer Affairs for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Utah Public Service Commis-
sion for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of
Arkansas, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae in No. 82-1331 is
granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
motions and these petitions.

to the Supreme Court of Alabama denied.

OPINIONS
No. 81-1244. C. Duane Hensley, et al., Petitioners v. Thomas
Eckerhart, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by
the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and
dissenting in part with whom Justice Marshall, Justice Blackmun and
Justice Stevens join.
No. 81–1983. Margaret H. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. Carmen Campbell. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Concurring opinion by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice
Marshall concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 82-34. American Paper Institute, Inc., Petitioner v. American
Electric Power Service Corporation, et al.; and

MONDAY, MAY 16, 1983
616
No. 82-226. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Petitioner v.
American Electric Power Service Corporation, et al. On writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 81-731. Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corporation, Appellant
v. Arkansas Public Service Commission. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Arkansas. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom the Chief Justice joins.
No. 82-185. Boston Firefighters Union, Local 718, Petitioner v. Bos-
ton Chapter, NAACP, et al.;
No. 82-246. Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, Inc., Petitioner
v. Pedro Castro, et al.; and
No. 82–259. Nancy B. Beecher, et al., Petitioners v. Boston Chapter,
NAACP, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to
the Court of Appeals for consideration of mootness in light of 1982
Mass. Acts, c. 190, Section 25. Opinion per curiam announced by the
Chief Justice. Justice Marshall took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these cases.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 23, 1983
623
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 82-1496. Harold Cardwell, et al., Petitioners v. Louis Cuen Tay-
lor. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam. Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall would grant the peti-
tion and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 80-1158. Florida, Petitioner v. Damasco Vincente Rodriquez.
The petition for rehearing is granted. The order entered May 26, 1981
denying the petition for a writ of certiorari is vacated. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District, for
further consideration in light of Florida v. Royer, 460 U.S. (1983).
Justice Brennan would deny the petition.
No. 82-328. Borden, Inc., Petitioner v. Federal Trade Commission.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit with directions that it remand
the case to the Federal Trade Commission for entry of the cease-and-
desist order to which the parties have agreed.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-341. In the Matter of Disbarment of Carl R. Scacchetti, Jr. It
is ordered that Carl R. Scacchetti, Jr., of Rochester, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

624
MONDAY, MAY 23, 1983
No. D-342. In the Matter of Disbarment of John David Baker. It is
ordered that John David Baker, of Rochester, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-343. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas Francis
McGrath, Jr. It is ordered that Thomas Francis McGrath, Jr., of Seat-
tle, Washington, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court
and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to
show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in
this Court.
No. D-344. In the Matter of Disbarment of Hugh William Stroh. It is
ordered that Hugh William Stroh, of Bellevue, Washington, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-345. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gordon Lee Walgren. It
is ordered that Gordon Lee Walgren, of Bremerton, Washington, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81–1044. United States Postal Service Board of Governors, Peti-
tioner v. Louis H. Aikens. The motion of respondent to retax costs is
denied. Justice Blackmun would grant this motion.
No. 81–2147. Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. San Carlos Apache Tribe
of Arizona, et al.; and Arizona, et al., Petitioners v. Navajo Tribe of
Indians, et al.; and
No. 81-2188. Montana, et al., Petitioners v. Northern Cheyenne
Tribe of the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation, et al. The motion
of respondents San Carlos Apache Tribe of Arizona, et al. for leave to
file a supplemental brief after argument is granted.
No. 82–357. Michigan, Petitioner v. Raymond Clifford and Emma
Jean Clifford. Further consideration of respondents' motion partially to
vacate the writ of certiorari as improvidently granted is deferred to the
hearing of the case on the merits.
No. 82–945. Sure-Tan, Inc. and Surak Leather Company, Petitioners
v. National Labor Relations Board. The motion of petitioners to pro-
ceed further herein in forma pauperis is denied. The motion of petition-
ers to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.

ters Local Union No. 1846, etc., et al. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

No. 82-6608. Carl Graham and Wayne Morris, Petitioners v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit denied.
No. 82-6623. John Jacob Welty, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit denied.
No. 82-6624. Michael Dean Williams, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 82-6630. Daniel Schlacks, Petitioner v. United States. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit denied.
No. 82-6639. James Larry Grainger, Petitioner v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 82-1319. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Department of Cor-
rections, Petitioner v. Alfred Eugene Grizzell. The motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit denied.
No. 82–1321. Kase Higa, Judge of the Second Circuit of Hawaii, Peti-
tioner v. Rory Mayo. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

630
MONDAY, MAY 23, 1983
No. 82-6483. Vernon Thaddeus Taliaferro, Petitioner v. Maryland.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland de-
nied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom Justice Brennan
and Justice Blackmun join.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 82–1761. In Re Gerald P. Hanson, Petitioner. Petition for writ of
habeas corpus is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 82-1746. In Re George L. Karapinka, Petitioner. Petition for
writ of mandamus is denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 81-6746. Hilario Medina-Pena, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 82-1328. Edmond Pfotzer and E. John Pfotzer, Petitioners v.
United States;
No. 82-1445. The Don't Bankrupt Washington Committee, Appellant
v. Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, et
al.;
No. 82-6238. Hurie Jones, et al., Appellants v. John Mitchell, et al.;
No. 82-6239. Joycelyn M. Jones, et al., Appellants v. Jefferson Par-
ish School Board; and
No. 82-6260. Alphonzo Harrison, Jr., Petitioner v. Oklahoma. Peti-
tions for rehearing are denied.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, May 24, 1983, until Tues-
day, May 31, 1983.

OPINIONS
No. 81-1062. United States, Petitioner v. Eight Thousand Eight
Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($8,850) in United States Currency. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81-2338. Donald T. Regan, Secretary of the Treasury, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Taxation with Representation of Washington; and
No. 82–134. Taxation with Representation of Washington, Appellant
v. Donald T. Regan, Secretary of the Treasury, et al. Appeals from
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The motion to dismiss in No. 82-134 is denied. Judgment reversed and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Brennan
and Justice Marshall join.
No. 82-502. Pallas Shipping Agency, Ltd., Petitioner v. Joseph
Duris. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.

MONDAY, MAY 23, 1983
639
No. 81-1463. United States, Petitioner v. Kelvin Hasting, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by the Chief Justice. Justice Blackmun would vacate the judg-
ment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case for consideration by
that Court of the issue whether the Fifth Amendment violation it per-
ceived to exist was harmless error within the measure of Chapman v.
California, 386 U.S. 18 (1967). Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring
in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Brennan concurring in part and dis-
senting in part with whom Justice Marshall joins.
No. 81–920. Verlinden B. V., Petitioner v. Central Bank of Nigeria.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 24, 1983
641
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 81-6633. Danny R. Bearden, Petitioner v. Georgia. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings not in-
consistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment with whom the
Chief Justice, Justice Powell, and Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 81-1661. General Motors Corporation, Petitioner v. Devex Cor-
poration, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Mar-
shall. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81-1891. Morrison-Knudsen Construction Company, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation, United States
Department of Labor, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief
Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81-3. Bob Jones University, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 81-1. Goldsboro Christian Schools, Inc., Petitioner v. United
States. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgments affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
Opinion by Justice Powell concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist.
Х
Adjourned until Tuesday, May 31, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1982
643
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.'
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
"
No. 82-1307. Lewis T. Graham, Jr., Appellant v. Louisiana. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-1663. Karl Fleischmann, Appellant v. Wethersfield Planning
and Zoning Commission, et al. Appeal from the Superior Court of
Connecticut, Hartford County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 82–1588. Lee M. Scarborough & Company, Appellant v. Thomas
P. Fox, etc., et al.; and
No. 82-1628. APS Insurance Agency, Inc., Appellant v. Thomas P.
Fox, etc., et al. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The ap-
peals are dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Justice
White and Justice Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set the
cases for oral argument.
No. 82-6075. Norman S. Schlang, Appellant v. Jack Heard, Sheriff.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82-6274. Hurie Jones, Appellant v. Orleans Parish School Board.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82-6496. Charles E. Counsell, Appellant v. Munro-Burns Gen-
eral Contractors. Appeal from the Intermediate Court of Appeals of
Hawaii. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.

644
TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1982
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1399. City of Los Angeles, Department of Water and Power,
et al., Petitioners v. Marie Manhart, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Hensley v. Eckerhart,
461 U.S.
(1983).
No. 81-1830. Earl B. Miller & Company, Petitioner v. Taylor
Hughes. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U.S. — (1983). Justice
Stevens dissents and would deny certiorari.
No. 82–156. City of Riverside, et al., Petitioners v. Santos Rivera, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U.S. (1983).
-
No. 82–192. Delta Air Lines, Inc., Petitioner v. Margaret Thorn-
berry, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U.S. — (1983).
-
No. 82-747. Christopher Bond, et al., Petitioners v. Calvin Burks, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of respondents for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U. S. (1983). Jus-
tice Blackmun and Justice Stevens dissent and would deny certiorari.
No. 82-816. Margaret H. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human
Services, Petitioner v. John Broz, et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
The motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is

TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1982
645
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Heckler v.
Campbell, 461 U.S. —, n. 8 (1983) (slip op. p. 6, n. 5).
No. 82-1335. James A. Rhodes, et al., Petitioners v. Larry Stewart.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light
of Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U.S. — (1983).
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-. Dorothy O. Kopituk, et al., Petitioner v. United States.
The motion of petitioners for leave to file an appendix to the petition for
writ of certiorari that does not comply with the Rules of the Court is
granted.
No. A-872. Khamis Khalil Dabeit, Applicant v. United States. The
application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. A-933. Michael Eugene Weech and Richard Vernon Wright, Ap-
plicants v. United States. The application to recall and stay the man-
date addressed to Justice Marshall and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-328. In the Matter of Disbarment of Martin Edward Juncker.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-330. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Jacob Bluestein.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-346. In the Matter of Disbarment of Frederick E. Hollings-
worth. It is ordered that Frederick E. Hollingsworth, of Boca Raton,
Florida, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-347. In the Matter of Disbarment of Read Rocap, Jr. It is or-
dered that Read Rocap, Jr., of Media, Pennsylvania, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-348. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gary A. Davis. It is or-
dered that Gary A. Davis, of Columbia, South Carolina, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

646
TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1982
No. D-349. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul A. Butler. It is or-
dered that Paul A. Butler, of South Natick, Massachusetts, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-350. In the Matter of Disbarment of Andrew A. Bucci. It is
ordered that Andrew A. Bucci, of North Providence, Rhode Island, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81-2159. Bill M. Silkwood, Administrator of the Estate of Karen
G. Silkwood, Deceased, Appellant v. Kerr-McGee Corporation, etc., et
al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 81–2169. Gilbert A. Haring, Lieutenant, Arlington County Police
Department, et al., Petitioners v. John Franklin Prosise. The motion of
respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief after argument is
granted.
No. 81-2245. Nevada, Petitioner v. United States, et al.;

United States, et al.; and
No. 82-38. Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe of Indians, Petitioner v.

erhood of Teamsters for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.

Services, Petitioner v. Mildred M. Edwards, etc. The motion of the So-

and Marty Ingels. The appeal as to appellee Ingels is dismissed. The

California, Second Appellate District, as to Ingels is denied.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 81–1374. Barbara Blum, individually and in her capacity as Com-
missioner of New York State Department of Social Services, Petitioner
v. Ellen Stenson, etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted.
No. 82-1253. Herman S. Solem, Warden, and Mark V. Meierhenry,
Attorney General of South Dakota, Petitioners v. John Bartlett. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit is granted.
No. 82-1005. Chevron U.S.A. Inc., Petitioner v. Natural Resources
Defense Council, Inc., et al.;
No. 82-1247. American Iron and Steel Institute, et al., Petitioners v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 82-1591. William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator, Environmen-
tal Protection Agency, Petitioner v. Natural Resources Defense Coun-
cil, Inc., et al. The motion of Mid-America Legal Foundation for leave
to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petitions for writs of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
Circuit are granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour
is allotted for oral argument.
No. 82-1330. Morris Thigpen, Commissioner, Mississippi Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. Barry Joe Roberts. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit granted.

whom Justice Brennan joins.

of Columbia Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari.
Justice Powell dissenting: I dissent from the denial of the petition for
writ of certiorari for reasons similar to those stated by Judge Wilkey in
his Statement as to Reasons for Voting for En Banc Consideration in
the Court of Appeals. App. to Petn. for Cert. 1a.

OPINIONS
No. 81-2125. Terrel H. Bell, Secretary of Education, Petitioner v.
New Jersey and Pennsylvania. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
Concurring opinion by Justice White.
No. 81-1314. W. R. Grace and Company, Petitioner v. Local Union
759, International Union of the United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum and
Plastic Workers of America. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun.
No. 81-2257. Bill Johnson's Restaurants, Inc., Petitioner v. National
Labor Relations Board. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment is vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals with instructions to remand the case to
the National Labor Relations Board for further proceedings in confor-
mity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice Brennan.
No. 81-1476. United States, Petitioner v. Lucille Mitzi Bosco Rodg-
ers, et al.; and United States, Petitioner v. Joerene Ingram, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth

TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1982
659
Circuit. Judgment in United States v. Rodgers is reversed and judg-
ment in United States v. Ingram is vacated. Both cases are remanded
to the Court of Appeals with directions that they be remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Brennan. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part
and dissenting in part with whom Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor join.
☑
Adjourned until Monday, June 6, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1983
661
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 82-1408. Ross Maggio, Jr., Warden, Petitioner v. John Fulford.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Opinion by Justice White concurring
in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Brennan with whom
Justice Stevens joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-1212. Jack Anthony Gullo, Appellant v. John F. McGill, et ux.
Appeal from the Circuit Court of Fairfax County, Nineteenth Judicial
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied. The Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist and Justice
O'Connor would award appellees damages pursuant to Sup. Ct. R. 49.2.
No. 82–1668. Cecelia Young, Appellant v. Town of Atlantic Beach.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Carolina. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1249. Donald L. Eide, et ux., Petitioners v. Julie Lelath Se-
guin. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of United States v. $8,850 in United States Currency,
461 U.S.
(1983).
No. 82–452. United States, Petitioner v. John von Neumann. On peti-

662
MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1983
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light
of United States v. $8,850 in United States Currency, 461 U.S.
(1983).
No. 82-1113. Duncanson-Harrelson Company, et al., Petitioners v.
Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, Department of
Labor, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Morrison-Knudsen Construction Company v.
Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, United States
Department of Labor, 461 U.S. - (1983).

dered that Vera L. Hoff, of San Jose, California, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring her to show cause why she should not be dis-
barred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Theodore Rosenberg, of Brooklyn, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 82-6686. Larry Leon Chaney, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
White and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Brennan
would grant the application. The petition for writ of certiorari to the

MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1983
671
Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma denied. Justice Brennan and
Justice Marshall dissenting: Adhering to our views that the death pen-
alty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by
the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S.
153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certiorari and vacate the death
sentence in this case.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 82-1669. In Re Jerry Wright, Petitioner. Petition for writ of pro-
hibition is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 82-524. Baltimore Gas and Electric Co., et al., Petitioners v.
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc. et al.;
No. 82-545. United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, et al.,
Petitioners v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al.; and
No. 82-551. Commonwealth Edison Company, et al., Petitioners v.

674
MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1983
Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice O'Connor. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.
No. 82–1066. United States, Appellant v. Harry Ptasynski, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the District of Wyoming.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the District Court for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Powell.
No. 81–1686. James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Western Nuclear, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Powell with whom Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.
No. 82-372. Federal Trade Commission, et al., Petitioners v. Grolier
Incorporated. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by
Justice Brennan concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with
whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 82-5576. Jeffrey Lee Pickett, etc., et al., Appellants v. Braxton
Brown, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Western
Division. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Tennessee for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1983
677
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall,
Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens,
and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 81-430. Illinois, Petitioner v. Lance Gates, et ux. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Rehn-
quist. Opinion by Justice White concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Brennan joins.
No. 82-215. United States, Petitioner v. Whiting Pools, Inc. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
No. 81-1020. Exxon Corporation, et al., Appellants v. Ralph Eager-
ton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of Alabama, et al.; and
No. 81-1268. Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation, et al., Appellants
v. Ralph P. Eagerton, Jr., Commissioner of Revenue of the State of
Alabama. Appeals from the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment af-
firmed in part, reversed in part and cases remanded to the Supreme
Court of Alabama for further proceeding not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81-2386. Philip DelCostello, Petitioner v. International Brother-
hood of Teamsters, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit; and
No. 81-2408. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC, et
al., Petitioners v. Donald C. Flowers and King E. Jones. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
The judgment in No. 81-2408 is reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. The judgment in No. 81-2386 is
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor.

678
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1983
No. 81–1487. BankAmerica Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White with whom Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall join. Justice
Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
✓
Adjourned until Monday, June 13 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1983
679
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-1701. David Schulz, Appellant v. Rockwell Manufacturing
Company, etc. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Second Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the pa-
pers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari is denied.
No. 82-6587. Gerald Glen Boyden, Appellant v. California. Appeal
from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82–1708. Farrell Mac Johnson, Appellant v. Texas. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Texas, Second Supreme Judicial District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-1714. Thomas R. Angel and Loretta C. Angel, Appellants v.
Louis H. Renn, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California,
Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 82–1727. Samuel Thomas Rickman, Appellant v. Georgia. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI -SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-56. Pearlie Simmons, et al., Petitioners v. Sea-Land Services,
Inc., et al. The petition for rehearing is granted. The order entered Oc-
tober 12, 1982 denying the petition for a writ of certiorari is vacated.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Pallas Shipping
Agency v. Duris, 461 U.S. (1983).

680
MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1983
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-360. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harry A. Tabenken. It is
ordered that Harry A. Tabenken, of Bangor, Maine, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-361. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Wright Moore, III.
It is ordered that John Wright Moore, III, of Houston, Texas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-362. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arnold Herman Crane. It
is ordered that Arnold Herman Crane, of Chicago, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 94, Original. State of South Carolina, Plaintiff v. Donald T.
Regan, Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. The motion for
a preliminary injunction is denied. The motion for leave to file a bill of
complaint is set for oral argument in due course.
No. 81-469. William C. Bush, Petitioner v. William R. Lucas. The
motion of respondent for leave to file a supplemental brief after argu-
ment is granted.
No. 81-2110. United Building and Construction Trades Council of
Camden County and Vicinity, Appellant v. Mayor and Council of the
City of Camden, et al. The motion of New England Legal Foundation
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 81-2332. Norfolk Redevelopment and Housing Authority, etc. v.
Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia, et al. The
motion of the Solicitor General for divided argument is granted. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 82-585. Aloha Airlines, Inc., Appellant v. Director of Taxation of
Hawaii; and
No. 82–586. Hawaiian Airlines, Inc., Appellant v. Director of Tax-
ation of Hawaii. The motion of Multistate Tax Commission, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.
No. 82-818. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Bildisco
and Bildisco, Debtor-In-Possession, et al.; and
No. 82-852. Local 408, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, etc.,

MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1983
681
Petitioner v. National Labor Relations Board, et al. The motion of
American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organiza-
tions for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of
the Solicitor General for divided argument is granted and a total of fif-
teen minutes is allotted for oral argument. The motion of petitioner in
No. 82-852 for divided argument is granted and a total of fifteen min-
utes is allotted for oral argument. The request of petitioner in No.
82-852 for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 82-862. Consolidated Rail Corporation, Petitioner v. Lee Ann
LeStrange Darrone, as Administratrix of Estate of Thomas LeStrange.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 82-940. Elizabeth Anderson Hishon, Petitioner v. King and Spal-
ding. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 82-1031. Jefferson Parish Hospital District No. 2, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Edwin G. Hyde. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argu-
ment is granted.
No. 82-914. Monsanto Company, Petitioner v. Spray-Rite Service
Corporation. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted
to be divided as follows: Counsel for petitioner: 20 minutes; the Solicitor
General: 10 minutes. Justice White took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 82-1041. Esther C. Dickman, et al., Petitioners v. Commissioner
of Internal Revenue. The motion of petitioners for divided argument is
denied.
No. 82–1608. South-Central Timber Development, Inc., Petitioner v.
Robert Le Resche, Commissioner, Department of Natural Resources of
Alaska, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 82-5934. John A. Garcia, Petitioner v. United States. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. The peti-
tioner is allowed until July 5, 1983, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. The Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist
and Justice O'Connor would award respondent damages pursuant to
Sup. Ct. R. 49.2.

682
MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1983
No. 82-6145. Elmo C. Tatum, Petitioner v. Regents of the Univer-
sity of Nebraska-Lincoln, et al. The motion of respondents for damages
is granted and damages are awarded to respondents in the amount of
$500.00 pursuant to Sup. Ct. R. 49.2. In all other respects, the motion
is denied. Justice Brennan, Justice Marshall and Justice Stevens would
deny the motion. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 82-6193. Noel Tancred Escofil, Appellant v. Pennsylvania. The
motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
The appellant is allowed until July 5, 1983, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 45(a) and to submit a jurisdictional
statement in compliance with Rule 33 of the rules of this Court. Justice
Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor would award appellee damages pursu-
ant to Sup. Ct. R. 49.2.
No. 82-6502. In Re Thomas L. Rush, petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. The petitioner
is allowed until July 5, 1983, within which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 45(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33
of the Rules of this Court. The Chief Justice, Justice Rehnquist and
Justice O'Connor would award respondents damages pursuant to Sup.
Ct. R. 49.2.

Corporation, et al.; and

the Second Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of
one hour is allotted for oral argument.

tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina de-
nied. Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 82-6728. In Re Clovis Carl Green, Jr., Petitioner. Petition for
writ of habeas corpus is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 82-6584. In Re Oscar E. Weigang, Jr., Petitioner;
No. 82-6598. In Re Clovis Carl Green, Jr., Petitioner; and
No. 82-6662. In Re Russell Kageler and Frank Mejia Ruiz, Petition-
ers. Petitions for writs of mandamus are denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 82–1344. Dorothy Cele, Petitioner v. Alfred R. Kinney, et al.;
No. 82-1376. Gurn H. Freeman, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 82–6172. Jimmy Lee Gray, Petitioner v. Eddie Lucas, Warden,
et al.;
No. 82-6187. Roy Allen Stewart, Petitioner v. Florida;
No. 82-6194. H. Wesley Copeland, Petitioner v. South Carolina;
No. 82–6324. Lionel E. Cyntje, Petitioner v. Government of the Vir-
gin Islands, et al.;
No. 82-6343. John David Smith, Petitioner v. Donald S. Borden-
kircher, Warden;

689
No. 82-6363. George Dallas Thompson, Petitioner v. Medical Officer
at Hamilton County Jail; and
No. 82-6436. In Re Ross E. Behrens and Ames DiPalma, Petitioners.
Petitions for rehearing are denied.

The Court will take a recess from Wednesday, June 15, 1983, until
Monday, June 20, 1983.

OPINIONS
No. 81–469. William C. Bush, Petitioner v. William R. Lucas. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring
opinion by Justice Marshall with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
• No. 82-5119. Nelson Bell, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment Affirmed. Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens.
No. 82-118. Crown, Cork & Seal Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Theo-
dore Parker. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Justice Powell with whom Justice
Rehnquist and Justice O'Connor join.
No. 82-331. New Mexico, et al., Petitioners v. Mescalero Apache
Tribe. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 81-2169. Gilbert A. Haring, Lieutenant, Arlington County Police
Department, et al., Petitioners v. John Franklin Prosise. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Marshall.
No. 82–167. George C. Chappell, et al., Petitioners v. Vernon Wal-
lace, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 15, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1983
695
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice Brennan, Justice White, Jus-
tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor.
OPINIONS
No. 82–131. Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, etc., Petitioner v.
Howard E. Pfeifer. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 81-746. City of Akron, Petitioner v. Akron Center for Reproduc-
tive Health, Inc., et al.; and
No. 81–1172. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, Inc., et al., Pe-
titioners v. City of Akron, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part and reversed in part and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this court.
Opinion by Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with
whom Justice White and Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 81-1255. Planned Parenthood Association of Kansas City, Mis-
souri, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. John Ashcroft, Attorney General of
Missouri, et al.; and
No. 81-1623. John Ashcroft, Attorney General of Missouri, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Planned Parenthood Association of Kansas City, Missouri,
Inc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. The integrated judgment is affirmed in part, re-
versed in part and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. The award of
attorneys' fees is vacated and the matter is remanded for further con-
sideration in light of Hensley v. Eckerhart, 461 U.S. (1983). Jus-
tice Powell delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I,
II, and VI, and an opinion with respect to Parts III, IV, and V, in
which the Chief Justice joins. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Brennan, Justice Mar-
shall, and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring
in part in the judgment and dissenting in part with whom Justice White
and Justice Rehnquist join.

696
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1983
No. 81–185. Chris Simopoulos, Appellant v. Virginia. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Powell. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concurring
in the judgment with whom Justice White and Justice Rehnquist join.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 82–168. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Transpor-
tation Management Corp. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White.
No. 82-342. Philko Aviation, Inc., Petitioner v. Maurice Shacket, et
ux. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in part and concurring in the judgment.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

tice Marshall, Justice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, and

OPINIONS
No. 81-984. First National City Bank, Petitioner v. Banco Para El
Comercio Exterior de Cuba. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom
Justice Brennan and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 81-1350. United States,
United States, Petitioner v. Jose Reynaldo
Villamonte-Marquez, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this court. Opinion by Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Brennan with whom Justice Marshall joins and with
whom Justice Stevens joins as to Part I.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
On Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master. Exceptions to the
Special Master's Report are sustained in part and overruled in part and
case returned to the Special Master for determination of the unresolved
issues framed in his Pre-Trial Order, in a manner consistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Brennan.
No. 81-2318. Florida, Petitioner v. Constantino Casal and Omar Gar-
cia. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The writ of
certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted, it appearing that the
judgment of the court below rested on independent and adequate state
grounds. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice. Concur-
ring opinion by the Chief Justice.
Adjourned until Monday, June 20, 1983 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
699
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Burger, Justice White, Justice Marshall, Jus-
tice Blackmun, Justice Powell, Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, and
Justice O'Connor.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 81-1782. City of Virginia, et al., Appellants v. George W.
Nyberg, et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. The motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Alan
Ernest to represent children unborn and born alive is denied. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied. Justice White and Justice Rehnquist would postpone further
consideration of the question of jurisdiction to a hearing of the case on
the merits. Justice O'Connor would dismiss the appeal for want of a
properly presented federal question.
No. 82-1188. Robert Kerrey, Governor of Nebraska, et al., Appel-
lants v. Women's Services, P. C., et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The motion of Alan Ernest to
represent children unborn and born alive is denied. The motion of Legal
Defense Fund for Unborn Children for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is denied. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of City of Akron v. Akron Center for Reproduc-
tive Health, Inc., 462 U.S.
(Part V) (1983). Justice Stevens
would affirm the judgment.
No. 82-1729. Marjorie Ann Miller, Appellant v. Municipal Court for
the County of Los Angeles, Pasadena Judicial District (California, Real
Party in Interest). Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certio-
rari is denied.
No. 82-6705. Rolf Betka, Appellant v. Glen R. Smith, et al. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The ap-

700
MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
peal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 82-1747. Ethel Hamilton, Administratrix, et al., Appellants v.
Wilford C. Stover. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Richland
County. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 82–1751. Donald E. Maynard, Appellant v. Sproul A. McGuiness,
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Montana. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82–1776. S. J. Groves & Sons Company, Appellant v. Illinois,
Acting through its Division of Highways of the Department of Trans-
portation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 82-6644. Ricci E. Lortz, Appellant v. California. Appeal from the
Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question
No. 82-6614. Astrid Galindo Sardoz and Maria Soto Vda. De
Talamantes, as Co-Personal Representatives, etc., Appellants v. Kent
Nowlin Construction Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
New Mexico. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly presented
federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 82-438. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Behring
International, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of National Labor Relations Board v. Transpor-
tation Management Corp. 462 U.S. (1983).
-
No. 82-736. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Heartland
Food Warehouse, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further
consideration in light of National Labor Relations Board v.
Transporation Management Corp., 462 U.S. (1983).
No. 82-1054. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs,
Warehousemen and Helpers, Local No. 988, Petitioner v. Norman E.

MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
701
Edwards, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of DelCostello v. International Brotherhood of Team-
sters, 462 U.S. (1983).
No. 82-1105. National Labor Relations Board, Petitioner v. Black-
stone Company, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further
consideration in light of National Labor Relations Board v.
Transporation Management Corp., 462 U.S. (1983).
No. 82-1481. Deborah Ann Astemborski, Petitioner v. Robert
Susmarski. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Pennsylvania, Western District. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District, for further consider-
ation in light of Pickett v. Brown, 462 U.S.
-
(1983).
No. 82-1549. United States, Petitioner v. Victor Domingo Garcia, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light
of United States v. Ross, 456 U.S. 798 (1982). Justice Stevens dissent-
ing: After the Court of Appeals denied the Government's petition for
rehearing in this case, the Government voluntarily moved to dismiss
the indictments. On January 12, 1983, the District Court granted that
motion. No one has ever challenged the effectiveness of the District
Court's order of dismissal, or sought to set it aside, either by a request
for rehearing in that court or by direct review on appeal. It is, there-
fore, perfectly clear that this litigation terminated a long time ago.
Nothing remains to be decided on the merits with regard to United
States v. Ross or any other issue.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . In the matter of Admission of Christopher A. Brose. The
application for admission to the Bar is granted. Dissenting opinion by
the Chief Justice.
No. D-363. In the Matter of Disbarment of Francesco Gigliotti. It is
ordered that Francesco Gigliotti, of New Castle, Pennsylvania, be sus-

702
MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 81-2332. Norfolk Redevelopment and Housing Authority, etc. v.
Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia, et al. The
motion of American Gas Association for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae is granted. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. 82-15. Ray E. Oliver, Petitioner v. United States; and
No. 82–1273. Maine, Petitioner v. Richard Thornton. The motion of
petitioner in No. 82-15 for divided argument is granted. The motion of
petitioner in No. 82-1273 for divided argument is granted.
No. 82–660. United States, Petitioner v. Harrison P. Cronic. The mo-
tion of respondent for substitution of counsel is granted and it is or-
dered that Steven B. Duke, Esquire, of New Haven, Connecticut, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case in place of
David W. Duncan, Esquire, of Durango, Colorado, who is hereby
discharged.
No. 82-708. Summa Corporation, Petitioner v. California ex rel.
State Lands Commission and City of Los Angeles. The motion of Pacific
Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
The motion of California Land Title Association for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of the Solicitor General for
leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided
argument is granted.
No. 82-940. Elizabeth Anderson Hishon, Petitioner v. King and Spal-
ding. The motion of New England Legal Foundation for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 82-1143. Miller Electric Company and Colgan Electric Company,
Inc., Petitioners v. National Constructors Association, et al.;
No. 82-1146. National Electrical Contractors Association, Inc., et
al., Petitioners v. National Constructors Association, et al.,; and
No. 82-1147. International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (AFL-
CIO) and Charles H. Pillard, Petitioners v. National Constructors As-
sociation, et al. The motion of the parties to defer consideration of the
petitions for writs of certiorari is granted. Justice Blackmun took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 82-1432. Gladys Pulliam, Magistrate for the County of
Culpepper, Virginia, Petitioner v. Richmond R. Allen and Jesse W.

MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
703
Nicholson. The motion of American Bar Association for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 82-1633. Hospital Building Company, Petitioner v. Trustees of
the Rex Hospital, et al.; and
No. 82–1762. Trustees of the Rex Hospital, et al., Petitioners v. Hos-
pital Building Company. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
these cases expressing the views of the United States.
No. 82-1651. Crispus Nix, Warden, Petitioner v. Robert Anthony
Williams. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is or-
dered that Robert Bartels, Esquire, of Tempe, Arizona, is appointed to
serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 82–282. Thomas C. McCain and William Spencer, etc., Appel-
lants v. Charles E. Lybrand, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of South Carolina. In this case probable ju-
risdiction is noted.
No. 82-1565. Bacchus Imports, Ltd., et al., Appellants v. George
Freitas, Director of Taxation of the State of Hawaii. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Hawaii. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 82–958. McDonough Power Equipment, Inc., Petitioner v. Billy
G. Greenwood, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 82-1643. Interstate Commerce Commission, et al., Petitioners v.
American Trucking Association, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
granted.
No. 81-757. W. Wayne Allen, Petitioner v. Inez Wright, etc., et al.;
and
No. 81-970. Donald T. Regan, Secretary of the Treasury, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Inez Wright, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit
granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one hour is allotted
for oral argument.
No. 82–1260. Copperweld Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Inde-
pendence Tube Corporation. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted limited to
Question 1 presented by the petition. Justice White took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.

MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
No. 82-1300. Virginia State Bar, et al., Petitioners v. Consumers
Union of United States, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 82–1301. Supreme Court of Virginia, et al., Petitioners v. Con-
sumers Union of the United States, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit de-
nied. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
Rehnquist joins. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of this petition.
No. 82–1471. Department of Revenue of the State of Montana, Peti-
tioner v. First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Missoula, et al.
The motion of Multistate Tax Commission for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Montana denied.
No. 82–1631. Potamkin Cadillac Corporation, Petitioner v. United
States. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit denied. The Chief Justice, Justice Rehn-
quist and Justice O'Connor would award respondent damages pursuant
to Sup. Ct. R. 49.2.
No. 82-1770. National Enquirer, Inc., Petitioner v. Superior Court of
California, County of Los Angeles (Shirley Jones and Marty Ingels,
Real Parties in Interest). Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeals of California, Second Appellate District, denied. Justice Bren-
nan and Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 82-6448. Ramon Pedro Hernandez, Petitioner v. Texas. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Dissenting statement by Justice Brennan and Justice Marshall.
No. 82-6474. Frank Smith, Petitioner v. Florida. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Justice Brennan dis-
senting: Adhering to my view that the death penalty is in all circum-
stances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and
Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231
(1976), I would grant certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this
case. Dissenting opinion by Justice Marshall.
COMMON LAW CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 82-6640. In Re Charles A. Damiano, Petitioner. The petition for
writ of certiorari is denied.

OPINIONS
No. 81-1617. United States, Petitioner v. Raymond J. Place. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Jus-
tice Brennan concurring in the result with whom Justice Marshall joins.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom
Justice Marshall joins.
No. 82-271. Carlos Chardon, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Juan Fumero
Soto, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice White and
Justice Powell join.
No. 82–411. Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company,
Petitioner v. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Rehnquist with whom Justice Powell joins.
No. 81-1859. Illinois, Petitioner v. Ralph Lafayette. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Appellate Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the
Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Marshall concurring in the judgment,
with whom Justice Brennan joins.
